150302505.review:
Another title to cross off my gaming bucket list.
The somewhat annoyingly clunky controls aside I really enjoyed the game's artistic aspects let it be the graphics themselves, the setting of street gangs competing for control with the inevitably batshiet insane storytelling concepts of Japanese game devs regarding [spoiler] transdimensional gods striving to take over a single random city [/spoiler] inevitably bleeding into the narrative, the law enforcement bringing out fohkin' tank platoons to fight a couple dozen of graffiti obsessed teens roaming the streets or the amazingly 2000s soundtrack that's half licensed tracks and half original compositions. That last point I found particularly surprising: you see I was not expecting to have a seamless auditory experience while playing this thing, but the composer indeed took the amazing extra step to create transitory segments between consecutive tracks where sampling from the next track randomly starts taking over the instrumental of the still ongoing one for a couple seconds before the real track itself begins. Sometimes the game is way too unforgiving and demands absolute precision despite it's not-so-great controls, but all things considered I had a fun time. Now, would someone, ANYONE please gimme a present day hardware based port of the supposedly Xbox (Classic) exclusive sequel of this game? That would be swell.

149405900.review:
Jet Set Radio is a rather enjoyable game. The controls take a little while to learn, but after a while you feel bodacious grinding rails and chaining combos. It is a little difficult, but I find it fun to play over and over again.
    The objective of the game is to cover rival gangs' tags, throw-ups, and pieces with your own, while avoiding the police. You move around on inline skates and can do all kinds of fun tricks. There are many unlockable characters you can have join your crew, and they have varying stats on attributes like speed and technique. You can design your own tags in multiple sizes in an in- game editor, (which I found very robust with many options,) or you can select from one of a number of pre- made designs. There is controller support (which I would recommend using). Again, the controls are pretty good once you learn it.
    Overall I would recommend adding this game to your steam library (I found myself not wanting to turn it off). It's very fun.

148444149.review:
Revisiting Jet Set Radio after first playing in back on the 360, it's still the joyous, upbeat, funkin' game that I remember! 

The music is phenomenally constructed, each track being just as memorable as the last; the blocky, stylistic look still remains remarkably attractive, and DJ Professor K is still the goat. All the characters have amazing, memorable designs, and the level design is superb. 

My only 2 gripes with this game is the controls and campaign runtime. Whilst I had not engaged with any of the side missions/levels, the main story only took me 3-4 hours to complete. That's 3-4 very fun hours, but just an extra hour or two would have been greatly appreciated. And the controls, while not horrendous, do feel quite floaty, leading to a weird feeling physics system. 

It was really fun going back to this 2000's hood classic, and one that I can highly recommend!

The soundtrack, the feel, the plot, the wild nature of military support being called in to deal with teenage punks just skating it up and doing some casual small-scale vandalism all amidst a skater gang turf war-all of these combine to create a massive hit. Fun, funky, fresh. That's this game's vibe.

[Deep, dramatic voice]

In a world where rebellious rollerbladers and graffiti artists rule the streets, where rhythm is your weapon, and where the term "obey" is a four-letter word... comes a game that defined a generation and transformed urban chaos into a vibrant playground. Welcome to the Honest Trailer for "Jet Set Radio!"

Get ready to lace up your skates and enter the colorful, cell-shaded, and slightly bizarre realm of Tokyo-to. But don't let the zany aesthetics fool you, because underneath the graffiti and funky tunes lies a world where freedom of expression takes center stage.

Witness a story that's a bit like "The Warriors" meets "Tony Hawk's Pro Skater," as you lead the GGs, a gang of rebellious, rollerblading graffiti artists. Fight against rival crews, the relentless police, and even aliens because, well, why not? This game answers the age-old question: "What if Tony Hawk had a rivalry with the men in black?"

But let's not forget the real star here: graffiti! Tag your way through Tokyo-to's various districts with your trusty spray can and show off your artistic skills. But beware, the police are always on your tail, trying to ruin your masterpiece with their oppressive "cleanup."

Enjoy a killer soundtrack featuring tracks from genre-defining artists like Hideki Naganuma and more. Each tune adds to the game's infectious energy, making you groove to the rhythm as you skate and spray.

Prepare yourself for tight controls, incredible style, and some wacky physics as you grind, flip, and tag your way through this underground masterpiece. Just remember, the camera can be your worst enemy at times, but hey, who needs it when you're this cool?

So, if you're ready to experience a game that's more hip and underground than your grandma's basement, with a level of nostalgia that will make you want to break out your rollerblades, it's time to revisit the classic that is "Jet Set Radio." Skate, tag, and groove your way through the streets of Tokyo-to and remember: "The streets don't lie."

146158288.review:
[h1]This is probably one of the most unique games you can ever play.[/h1]

Jet Set Radio is a funky, unique action platforming/skating game. It's probably one of the most iconic games of SEGA's lineup.

The controls are okay for a controller, just the speed-up and slight tank controls that are a bit niggly [b](keep in mind, this game released in 2000).[/b] The levels are all interesting, the vibe is immaculate, the music is good, and it keeps you engaged and adds to the game's vibe.

So, of course, this game consists of you skating around town and spraying graffiti all over the place in defiance of the congolmerate called the Rokkaku Group. The story is not exactly the most memorable story you'd find, but it rounds out the game a bit with some lore. The gameplay is fun and funky. The addition of police officers shooting at and using flamethrowers against a simple graffiti-spraying rollerskater may seem a bit extreme. But it's what also adds to the uniqueness and interestingness of the game.

To me personally, the price is a bit high but not too high. [b] I'd recommend you get this classic game for a steal while on sale.[/b]

145806548.review:
TL;DR, if you have access to one of the other consoles this is on, get this game there.  This port has some issues, but if it's your only option then don't pass up the chance to play the game.

Let me preface this by saying JSR is a bit of an oddball among SEGA's DC-era franchises.  The controls are somewhat stiff, and while serviceable for the game it definitely makes things harder for beginners than other games (including its own Sequel and BRC).  But at the same time, the game's artstyle and soundtrack are unrivaled-- Hideki Naganuma and the other artists are masters of their craft, Rob Zombie is there for some reason, it's Iconic.  The game loop is simple yet addicting despite the controls, with chaining tricks and whatnot being extremely satisfying.  I could go on, it's very much a Style over Substance kinda game but in the best way (that being that the Substance isn't far behind).

But this is also the kind of game I'd suggest nabbing on another console.  This port is... not that great, as has been the case with a lot of the Steam DC ports sadly.  Notably, the game doesn't like to load properly on startup off a fresh install-- you have to go in and literally swap the Config and Game names in the files for it to run.  And certain graphical effects, namely the little light trails when you jump or go fast enough to trick, simply stop working if you play on resolutions above 720p.

In short, if you have a DC, 360, or PS3, get the game there.  If not, then do know that there WILL come some trouble trying to get the PC port to work.  Otherwise, great game, definitely try it out.

The game itself is great, a true classic that has a few flaws (the major one being its controls...) that shouldn't keep people from playing. Jet Set Radio has a lot of style, and it's deserving of your time. I played this game on the original Dreamcast, and it's easily one of the best games on the entire system. Even the sequel/spiritual successor Jet Set Radio Future--which is an overall huge improvement on this game--doesn't surpass this game when it comes to pure aesthetics. This is a truly special game.

However, this port is awful. I can't get past the 3rd level because the game will just randomly crash, and when I looked up how to stop the game from crashing... there's no real solution. Even the speedrunning community for this game can't solve all the crashing problems, and uses a 3rd party application to try and prevent the game from crashing. I tried using that application, and the game just froze instead of crashing.

Great game, bad port that will probably never be fixed. Thankfully, there's other ways to play this game, and I implore you to do so.

145211606.review:
I will say that going through Jet Set Radio is not an easy task. First, she lets you into the land of dreams, after which you go into the abyss, filled with a lot of torment and suffering until the very end. This does not happen immediately, but afterwards you stumble on every ledge in the hope of passing the level.

But let's start not with this, but with the individuality of this product. This is a truly great game that has its own style, original music by Hideki Naganuma and gives you the opportunity to express yourself in all colors. In addition, it has a very interesting level design, in which you can get confused at some point, but once you understand the movement, you understand at the click of your fingers where you painted over, where you didn't paint over, where you got, and where you didn't have to get.

Further, cops are a separate conversation. Here I am ready to pay tribute to the SEGA company, they stuffed up to the very throat. These devils are very heavy in the later stages of the game, and if it seemed to you that tanks are not a problem, try to fight off the gang pack on jetpacks with machine guns in your hands. I assure you, you will not get bored :)

Anyway, the most curious thing I noticed about this game is how it teaches you. At first you are happy, then you get high, the high turns into anger because of the stupid controls and the police officers embracing the character from all sides, but slowly you begin to memorize tracks, a movement, use different tactics to complete the level, try to do more (or less), which, in the end, is rewarded with rank. And yes, there are about six ranks there, and the latter are not very bad, and at the same time not comforting, it still spurs a person to get better results.

Actually, that's all I wanted to say, I passed it only today.

Thank you for your attention, good luck in your endeavors!

144832413.review:
[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Jet Set Radio"[/h1]

Jet Set Radio fue originalmente publicado en Japón el 29 de Junio del 2000 para Sega Dreamcast y a día de hoy no sólo sigue siendo recordado con cariño, pues tambien su estilo visual cel-shading y dinámica frenética sirvió de inspiración para títulos más recientes como Bomb Rush Cyberfunk o Hi-Fi RUSH.

Su jugabilidad refinada (Para la época), ni tan complicada y ni tan simple, y su brillante banda sonora elaborada por Hideki Naganuma, lo que convierte a Jet Set Radio en un clásico inolvidable. 

En 2012 SEGA lo republicó para PC en Steam junto a otros tantos clásicos como Valkyria Chronicles, ahora sólo faltaría Jet Set Radio Future.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Excelente juego, lo recomiendo bastante.

144825603.review: Right off the bat this game is locked to 30 fps so that's already enough for that refund button. The next issue which is honestly a bigger problem is the controls. Yeah its a dreamcast game so you already know the clunk was on the way but pairing that with a not great camera, extremely slow character speed that takes some work to build up with a slippery slide to boot makes the game just feel super unpolished. Can you get used to it? Sure. Should you? That's up to you. This game really shows its age considering lot of games that dropped in the same era control much tighter and is way more responsive (jesus the graffiti prompts don't even trigger properly 80 percent of the time) For its time it was really something special but revisiting this many years later I cannot in good conscious recommend this title. Especially when other titles already do what this game does so much better. Go play Hover or Bomb Rush Cyberfunk.

144130745.review:
Quick:

5/5 

This is one of my favorite games.  Jet Set Radio is a unique game, that has become somewhat of a cult classic with the help of its even better sequel Jet Set Radio Future.  It has an interesting story and premise, with a whole cast of colorful and likable characters.  When you play the game, you feel good about everything that you're doing.  The tone is lighthearted and a little bit comical, which can be perfect if you're looking for a game that is challenging, yet also relaxing.



More:

I remember when Jet Set Radio first released.  The cel shaded graphics were still somewhat new at the time, and it helped the game to stand out.  It looks great, even today, and is one of my favorite aspects of the game.  There is a strong 90's aesthetic in the game, with bright colors and almost retro-ish character designs all over the place.  Spray painting or tagging is the main mechanic of the game, so naturally the spray painted graffiti art style makes itself apparent everywhere.  

Visually the game is as good looking as it is unique.  There is a simplicity to the models and the environment that is complimentary to the style.  You could look at the game and tell that it's low-poly, but it does not feel that way.  When you play the game, it feels as though it looks the way it's supposed to look. 

Music is very important to this franchise.  Some of my favorite songs actually come from the Jet Set Radio games.  When I was younger, and playing this game with my friends, we would often sing along to the tracks.  They're very memorable and upbeat.  Sometimes we would even play some of them in the car when we rode around town while not playing the game.  I have a feeling that the music in the game is one of the things that most fans will hold up as an iconic identifying feature of the game.

The characters are all great.  You play as a group of graffiti artists on jet powered roller blades that grind on rails all over the city spray painting over rival gang's graffiti with your own.  Your group, the GG's, has a bunch of characters to choose from that are all different and cool in their own way.  They have different stats as well, which makes them play slightly differently.  Everyone probably has a favorite character, but I doubt anyone 'hates' any one of them.

If you've played 'collect-a-thons' in the past, then you might like the game-play in Jet Set Radio.  You don't necessarily collect items to complete the levels, but it's somewhat similar.  You begin each level with the goal of finding and tagging all the rival gang's graffiti.  There are enemies that follow you around and try to stop you, and there is a time limit for each level.  Every now and then there are the equivalent of boss fights, in which you have to fight against rival gangs or by spray painting the body of an actual boss character.  

The world is a city that I assume is in Japan, or is just styled that way.  There are many memorable locations, and it feels great navigating across the rooftops or through the sewers at high speed while tagging different locations.  This game is a triumph of various disciplines coming together to make something unique and fun in the gaming world.

140000239.review:
JSR is still a fabulously creative and fun game, even today.
...for a while anyway.

First of all, it's riddled w/ bugs. I needed to learn how to use a hex editor for the first time (on my steam deck which just complicated things) just to fix some code that was keeping the game from saving properly. But once you get that out of the way, it'll still crash and freeze periodically, often right after you finish a level, so you'll have to play it all again.

As for the game itself, the controls are a bit glitchy, and often don't respond the way you want them to. It’s fine in the beginning, but when the levels start opening up (and the in game map is THAT bad), the paint spots increase and spawn in harder to reach areas, and the enemy spawns get cheaper and cheaper, then "quirky" controls become game-ruining inconveniences.

JSR is fun, and you can get maybe hours of fun out of it before you reach your breaking point like I did. But I can't recommend anyone seek it out or call it a must play.

Definitely check out the S-tier soundtrack though

Update:  Bombrush Cyberfunk came out, and that is basically JSR fixed.  As a spiritual successor to JSR, it's an easy recommendation

I definitely appreciate what this game did in terms of bringing innovative music and art to a new audience, but it's super frustrating to try to play in the modern era of smooth controls and clear direction. It's frustrating to miss a collectible and wander around a nonsensical map looking for some obscure secret area that's totally mandatory, and it's doubly frustrating when your character controls like he's performing a prostate exam on a man made of partially melted caramel.
I get what the art and music direction goes for, tying in to the very rebellious nature of the game's plot, but it's ultimately just a headache for me. Hideki Naganuma has a handful of great tracks, but the majority of them are just bad sampled beats that aren't long enough to fit the level and feel like rubbing my face against sandpaper at 30 miles per hour. It's not that I don't like art with high-contrast color or electronic/"jungle" music, but the presentation of those art styles by jet set radio is less groovy and more lobotomizing.

138451005.review:
In middle school, I thought cool kids were like in Jet Set Radio where they skated in their free time and tagged dumpsters by the mall. In reality, our "cool kids" did nothing but drink cheap beer near the paper mill, but this vibrantly-colored punk fantasy has pervaded in my mind consistently since then. I don't believe punk as a movement ever existed as a squeaky clean expression of self that JSR so lovingly evangelizes. However, the game world is such a stylish and fun expression idea of punk that I want it to be real. It's effortlessly charming.

Game controls are unorthodox and by playing you can tell the game was being developed before Tony Hawk's Pro Skater. The tutorial is vague in communicating how tricks are performed and what contributes to how far you fly after jumping. The skating parkour system is consistent so it is learnable, but man is it annoying at times as you build that muscle memory.

Loved the game overall, so now I gotta find an OG Xbox to play Jet Set Radio Future on.

138351268.review:
This game is a blast. It was so ahead of it's time that it's hard to believe.
Forming a gang of cool grafiti painting skaters is a good concept on it's own, but the devs hav complemented it with amazing visual style and soundtrack, making it a very consistent and impressive experience.
The game has one small downside, however. It's the learning curve. As many people have noted, Jet Set Radio has quite unusual controlls. I wouldn't say that they are bad, but they need time to get used to. Most of my first playthrough consisted of constant overshooring/missing the rails, getting killed by enemies and so on. BUT! Soon enough i started feeling the movement and it became amazing. The game gives plenty of opportunities to grind on rails, jump on walls and this gives you a feeling of being an unstoppable grafiti painting machine. I loved it so much that I eventually completed it 100%. 
Very fun game. Has some downsides, but it's more than worth Your time.

Hideki "poganuma" Naganuma is responsible for many of the beloved tracks in this game. the man is a legend of funk. This game also features a song that i didnt re-discover until I was an adult and this remaster came out: Stop the Rock by apollo 440. its an absolute banger.

The gameplay is also rad as hell. weirdly I would probably compare movement to something like mirrors edge, in the sense that moving quickly is mostly about finding ways to gain momentum and preserve it. when you stop to commit "BIG VANDALISM" you want to be quick and you want to get back to moving quick, you are literally on a timer, and the Japanese cops in this game were based off info about the modern American police force that an intern pulled from a time machine. They legit get so mad at you they send an attack helicopter. 

The graphics hold up way better than i could have imagined. This game is a perfect example of the concept "graphics are temporary, art direction is forever". the cell shaded style is visually clean, and looks even better than it did on Dreamcast what with the higher resolution and such. AND you dont even need a goofy ass huge memory card (that were fucking hard to find) hanging out of your controller.

Story is... well its not great truth be told. the final stage Features a very weird (and story relevant) track that i dont hate, but it feels like its intentionally messing with the vibe. Its also super short. But you can go back and try to get better rankings and just sorta jam out. maybe try out another character. 

its also $8 lol. just buy it ya ding dong.

137194623.review:
This game might not be for you, it wasn't for me. 

First and foremost, it's mechanics aren't as well explained as it pretends they are. The tutorial walks you through the basics, but does so in the most painfully slow way possible. What isn't explained is the battery powered roller blades. You don't really have no meter telling you how much power is left, only a little exclamation marker above your head telling you can't use them.

Second, it feels more floaty than a game like this should. It makes it far more difficult to gauge how far you're going to jump. What is worse, your jumps where you do tricks throw you off even more. This point I feel crushes my enjoyment while trying to get through the tutorial.

And third, achieving the goal of the game, doing graffiti, is achieved in the most annoyingly round-about way possible. You need to grab pickups in order to actually do said graffiti. I can hold suspension of disbelief for that, but I also have a limited battery in my super powered roller blades?

If you like the music, which is a fair opinion, you'd be better off waiting for a modern remaster or sequel to deliver on a unique experience rather than putting yourself through a game whose mechanics were poorly put together even for it's time.

136782396.review:
Jet Set Radio is a classic for a reason. A fantastic soundtrack, a world absolutely dripping in cool and exciting high-speed rollerskating all came together to make one of the most fun game experiences out there.

Be aware that the game is from the year 2000, and while the stylized graphics have aged beautifully, the gameplay retains the jank that more modern games have more or less gotten rid of. For instance, there's no quick restart if you fuck up a mission, and you will likely find yourself frustrated quite often as you lightly touch the side of a car and go flying, or find yourself unable to dismount a mind-numbingly slow grind. The game's faults are easily outweighed by all the things it does well, but it is probably good to approach the experience with the proper expectations.

135061020.review:
Jet Set Radio is a Sega Dreamcast classic, remastered for more modern hardware in 2012.
It’s easy to why this game was beloved. The cel-shaded graphics are beautiful to look at, even if blocky by modern standards. The game has a great ambient, with street vibes accompanied by a great original soundtrack.
Unfortunately, there’s something nasty about the game. Very, very nasty. The gameplay SUCKS. Seriously, there’s so much wrong with this game. The controls lack precision, especially when in the air, making jumps feel like a lottery most of the time. Good luck trying to jump into grind spots, and even more trying to jump off it to where you want. Wall jumping is even worse. You’ll get stuck in stupid places, with the camera not helping.
But you won’t need to play very far to see the issues. Just play the stupid “tutorial”. Some tasks aren’t intuitive or well explained, and the last one requires you to get a combo of 50 tricks, which trust me, unless you already have some experience with the game, will be an exercise in frustration.
With practice, you’ll definitely improve and learn some tips to better control your jumps, but my experience until that point was one of the most frustrating ones I’ve ever had in gaming. I’ve had my share of hard games, but the good ones make you feel it’s your fault when losing. Here, I lost count of my swearing against this game and it’s BS gameplay.
On top of that, there’re the enemies, which are alright on their own, but are super annoying when juggling the crap controls at the same time.
The boss battles are also another problem. The objective is to get behind rivals and tag them multiple times. They are a bit challenging, but what I have an issue with is the bad hitbox detection for tagging and the stupid decision to put the tagging button on the same button as the camera reset. Seriously, in this remaster a lot of buttons on the controller aren’t even used, so there’s no excuse for this. It’s so annoying trying to tag rivals just for the camera to randomly juggle around because the tag failed, so the camera gets reset instead.
Then there’re the achievements, requiring for example that you get the best rating for every level. I don’t have a problem with them. What I have a problem with is the fact that you can’t retry a level mid-way. Why??? Not being a feature in the original release doesn’t excuse the lack of its implementation here. It just makes things much harder, especially because you can’t replay story levels. There’s a retry option after you beat a level, but once you’re back on your hub, you have complete the game first and then catch up to where you were.
These are some of the biggest issues I have with the game, but there are way more, most related to the level design. I can see the appeal of the game, as it definitely looks and sounds cool when looking at good gameplay footage. That’s what dragged me in. But I can’t forgive it for the frustration it gave me, especially in the first hours. And for me, gameplay is way more important than graphics or style. So, my advice is to STAY AWAY from this. In this case, nostalgia just isn’t worth the experience.

134979095.review:
Yes, the cel-shaded graphics were revolutionary at the time, and yes, the OST is solid, but viewing Jet Set Radio (2000) through a modern lens reveals a game whose strong creative vision is blotted out by a woeful user experience. I can forgive some issues in an era-adjusted sense, as it is a first-generation 32-bit game, but below is a list of issues I can't look past:

* (Pause Menu) Cannot choose to restart stage from the beginning.
* (Pause Menu) Cannot end/save stage immediately (specifically, upon gathering all Graffiti souls for a given area)
* Cannot stage select while in NG+ i.e. if you miss a Jet ranking in Story mode, you have to play through the story *again* until you reach the desired stage.
* Dash-jumping is faster than regular dashing. It's kind of a necessity since trick-looping is required in Technique mode, but still.
* Graffiti occasionally gives +50 to score but there's no documentation in-game regarding how to receive the bonus.
* Hit detection to jump onto cables/tightropes is...not great. No visual clarity among them either - black cables in a dark setting (Benten, Grind Square) doesn't build confidence. You end up having to 'feel' your way through a stage more than seeing it, and it's a painful learning curve for when you're just starting out on any given stage.
* (Technique mode) When time is up, your character stops completely. This means your character can and will fall to the ground, potentially causing damage.

* The majority of the time you collide with anything, expect to lose all speed/velocity and take 100% of the 'loss' during the impact. The next few points deal with similar issues.
* Every time you collide with a rival in a race, you take damage and knock-back while the rival is completely unaffected. 
* Uneven terrain is infuriating to 'interact' with. The best example of this is the ground-touching lift in Grind Square: it's marginally off the ground, so you can't skate onto it directly - you have to hop onto it.
* Angled surfaces can leave you stuck. the half-pipe in Shabuya and the sewer loops in Kagone are notorious for stopping you outright while being on a 30-degree incline. And good luck trying to jump off the half-pipe and through a door to stairs, you can miss that and lose a Jet Crush in that one moment alone.
* If you're hit by a car, it has the potential to knock you onto its roof and then drive out-of-bounds, forcibly ending the stage.

* (Shabuya) The "connecting" screen between the three main areas is disorienting upon first discovery, as the directional controls change immediately (or shortly?) upon transition. 
* (Benten/Kogane) Rooftops are uneven, sometimes causing your character to temporarily be unable to dash or jump, the only two forms of generating speed. This can and will result in occasionally stumbling off of the roofs and onto the ground.
* (Kogane: Fight or Flight) Sewer -> Fall into water -> You can spawn immediately into paratrooper gunfire, which knocks you back into the water you just climbed out of. 
* (Bantam Street: Jet Crush) You have to spray the vertical surface of the designated target, which is not immediately obvious as it's the only instance of an elevated vertical-facing spray-target in the game.
* (Grind Square) It's possible to be standing on the lift and have policemen grab you before the lift rises and/or when it's just starting to rise. 
* (Grind Square) Point thresholds for Jet rankings are 15-20% too high across the board. Philosophically, you shouldn't have to engage in infinite Technique loops to get a Jet rating in Graffiti mode.

I could be cynical and say something snide like "Jet Set Radio is only popular because you pirated it when you were 11 years old, and engaging in vandalism while being shot at by paratroopers/tanks/helicopters shamelessly fueled your prepubescent woe-is-me persecution complex" - and let's be honest, audience, I'd be right - but I'm not going to say that. 

Instead, I ask you to consider why a game has a 90%+ positive rating but less than 7.5% of its owner base reached the ending.

134895510.review:
Absolutely incredible! This game holds up fairly well, albeit with some minor hiccups, I find. The movement feels nice, but I do find the dash you have doesn't last nearly as long as I wish it did. There are some issues with the geometry at times and I find some areas with slopes to really kill the enjoyment for a moment. These are all pretty minor, but may build up. The only big nitpick, for me, were the enemies in the game. Some you are able to get off of you, but I found the ones that couldn't be removed were frustrating at times, especially when you had an x-large pattern you needed to perform.

But what you're going to be playing this game for, and what probably interested you in the product to begin with, was the aesthetic. And needless to say, the music and art direction and perfection. Even with the minor gripes I had, I found myself beaming every moment from the fantastic sound and music. As well as wanting to jump right back in and see this beautiful world around me. I'm usually on the side that I would rather take a game with a style and personality over graphical fidelity, and this is just another example of style holding up so well.

Lastly, my playthrough did last be about 4ish hours, but just means you can keep on coming back for more and it won't be a huge time investment, as well as grinding out those high scores, if you want. This is a high recommend for me!

131596072.review:
Short but sweet (soul brother)

Two decades later and Jet Set Radio is still a great game. Luckily the visual style keeps the game looking quite fresh despite 23 years worth of patina. The movement and camera controls do show some age, but not to a degree that you can't get used to them. Once you do, the movement does actually become rather nice and ever-so stylish. And the soundtrack is still one of the all-time greats.

My second playthrough of the main story only took around 4.5 hours after having beaten it for the first time in 2014, so it's definitely not the longest. I imagine first-time players will progress through the game a bit slower than I did though. However, there is still more content and collectibles to grind out if the main story isn't enough skating action.

I would definitely recommend this piece of gaming history. It is, if nothing else, a stylish and fun little snack.

As an added bonus, played basically perfectly on my Steam Deck and with good battery life.

130950115.review:
This is one of those must-play classic games. This is basically a flow platformer with some tricky precision execution thrown in. Don't let the tricky controls scare you off; this game gets better the more you play it and the better you get at it. It frustrates you with slow base speed, but the trick is that you gain speed every time you jump, encouraging you to jump and wall-jump and trick and grind and just generally go ballistic until you're every bit as frenetic and wild as the music this game blasts at you.

It's a one-of-a-kind experience. First impression is rough, but it's 100% worth it to reach that awesome experience you get once you're good at it. The graphics are primitive but charming, the music is great, and the theming and story, if basic, are on-point. Nothing else does what Jet Set Radio does, so dive right in and keep practicing and having fun with it until you get that awesome Thanks for Playing screen. Soak it in; games like this come very rarely.

If you want more detail, this game requires some advanced technique-chaining. It's got a vibe like Mario 64, but with even more emphasis on momentum and planning your moves ahead, and with more consistently-good level design (Mario 64's early levels are great, but most people dislike those like Rainbow Ride. Jet Set Radio's got one questionable level set on Wall Street, but it holds up better overall. I played them back-to-back.)

The sheer joy of chaining moves, flowing around a stage and dodging the Rokkaku goons is priceless.

128942393.review:
For someone who has never grew up with the dreamcast as I had been born a few years after 2001 when it was deemed a "flop" by sega as they moved on to making games for the other 6th gen consoles instead, I think this game is all around great, the aesthetic, the music, and even the gameplay is pretty damn fun. 

Although yes, there's other reviews that say the gameplay is clunky and controls like ass, but once you get used to the controls, physics, and how things work, it can be a lot of fun grinding rails and spray painting billboards and such. But I'm not saying it's perfect either, as it's very apparent during some frustrating missions in the game that make the game not so fun. Despite all that, I found the other missions to be fun, even if I mess up tricks quite a bit. I feel that this game still holds up well to this very day if you have an deep appreciation of older games like I do, but I think anyone could enjoy this game, even if they hadn't played much older games, it's just that they need the patience and dedication in order to get used to the controls, but it's much harder nowadays because games are becoming easier for anyone to pick up and start playing, making it more accessible for even someone who has never played a game before to start playing just fine, which is great, I'm all for that, but I wish everyone could appreciate older games and truly try to play them longer until they gotten used to the controls just enough to see if they like the game or not instead of quitting the game after a few or more minutes from not being able to do the cool shit right away, as some people are like that, they don't give older games the chance they deserve, but that's just me, agree or disagree as you wish.

Anyways, most of us can all agree that the style and the aesthetic of this game is absolutely amazing, it perfectly captures the essence of the late 90s and it's obsession with the "millennial future" that was so popular at the time. Overall the game is super colourful, bright and cheerful that'll surely make most people smile and have a great time staring at while they play. And the music, oh my god the music..it's one of the best. Hideki Naganuma did an excellent job on the soundtrack, along with everyone else who worked on it. A lot of these tracks are absolute bops like let mom sleep and humming the bassline. 

Here's my list of my favourite tracks in the game:
-Let Mom Sleep
-Humming The Bassline
-Miller Ball Breakers
-Everybody Jump Around
-Magical Girl
-Up-Set Attack
-Mischievous Boy
-Sneakman
-'Bout the City
-Sweet Soul Brother 
-Super Brother 
-Rock It On

These are my personal favourites, but they're still other great tracks in the game that deserve the attention for sure, although I personally find the final boss music "Grace and Glory" not as good as the other tracks in the game, but that's about it, everything else, I enjoy.

Overall, I say give it a chance if you hadn't played much older games, and a must play if you have a deep appreciation for older games and don't mind the jank that comes with older games. Thanks for reading this lengthy review. ^^

128427183.review:
Interesting characters and story, great visuals / art direction and amazing music are the major highlights of this game, and they carry it enough for me to almost want to recommend this game just for those aspects alone.
 
However, the clunky and sometimes dated controls make playing this game, especially through the later levels (Grind Square & the Golden Rhino stages especially, the latter of which was so frustrating that it made me drop the game) a chore.  The camera, while serviceable, gets annoying within tight areas / when you're trying to see what new enemy is just around the corner, ready to stun lock you before you can even think of running away. Jumping off rails is a gamble between overshooting / undershooting where you want to go, and trying to stop yourself after landing on a tiny platform? Nah. (I tried playing this game with a controller AND KBnM, the latter was more enjoyable for me.) 

I get that maybe this is just a me issue and that I just need to 'get good', but if it wasn't for everything else surrounding this game I wouldn't recommend it.  Jet Set Radio is an amazing work of art, from its wonderful cel-shaded graphics to it's amazing soundtrack, but I just wish it was also a good game.

125856020.review:
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/tldreview/discussions/4/3541546590719112669/]Like always, here's the full review text that wouldn't fit here.[/url]

I've had this game forever, and I don't know why I avoided it for so long. I got to the end after about 5.9 hours according to Steam. 

[h1]What is [i]Jet Set Radio[/i]?[/h1]
It's a rerelease of a Dreamcast game, originally called [i]Jet Grind Radio[/i] in the States for some reason. This is sort of a sportsy action game where you take one of several different rollerblading youths and have to tag (spray spray paint on) different buildings and billboards and cars and so on while doing fancy tricks. 

It's all out gang warfare in the streets of Tokyo-to! Instead of blasters, these rudies are armed with cool skates and spray paint! Fight off the other gangs as you express your art (right on top of theirs, haha!) and watch out for the cops and other goons who are more than willing to use deadly force! 

[h1]What Worked For Me[/h1]
[b]Music[/b]
I think the music carries this game. Even when I'd run out of time (999 seconds?!?), or when I'd repeatedly fail to win a race or copy a rival, the songs kept me going, and several of them aren't even bad to listen to outside of the game. I won't say it's the best gaming soundtrack ever, but it just fits this game so well. There are some licensed tracks, but Hideki Naganuma's sampled tracks are something else, too. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Despite my issues with the controls or my lack of aim, the main gameplay loop was pretty engaging. It's fun to screw around and do tricks, and the very minor puzzle element in finding good places to tag before the authorities get serious was interesting. Like I said with the replay value section, if you're the type to chase high scores, then this will be a big draw too. And because of the way the missions are structured, you're not stuck in 'tag the town' hell or whatever else for too long, so there's quite a lot of variety, too.  

[b]Premise[/b]
Gang 'violence' being solved with the use of graffiti while the police and corrupt corporations try to erase you with extreme prejudice? What the hell is wrong with Tokyo-to?! There's something playfully goofy about the setting and story despite the stakes being high and all. When you hear the police captain radio in [i]tanks[/i] with no concern for the consequences to deal with teenagers putting up graffiti, you know you're in for something ridiculous. There's potential for the game to swing into dark topics like the abuse of authoritative power and all, but the game keeps things cartoony and silly, and nobody (except one character off-screen) really gets hurt. 

[h1]What I Didn't Like[/h1]
[b]Camera[/b]
This is a two-parter.

First, the camera has an unfortunate tendency to be a hindrance if you're near a wall since it'll collide with it and screw up where you're looking. It does fine anytime else, but if you're in tight spaces, prepare for pain. The second part really comes into play during the 'tag the rival gang' missions. Because you have to hit the left trigger to tag and the left trigger also repositions the camera, it can get very disorienting if you repeatedly hit the button but aren't yet close enough to actually tag them. There were several unused buttons on the Dreamcast even, so why wasn't one of those buttons used for centering the camera instead? 

[b]VS gang battles[/b]
This kind of ties to the above about mashing left trigger causing the camera to repeatedly center itself, but it's pretty difficult to tag people in the back ten times each while you're trying to chase them down, and it absolutely must be in the back--though you're likely going to get knocked back or down if you approach the enemy from the front when they're standing still. You can tag while grinding, but my frustration was just from constantly playing catch up and having to spam LT to hope I hit them enough times while their back was turned.

[b]No stage select...at first[/b]
There were a few times I wanted to just hit one of the stages I cleared already and just screw around or try to explore to figure out routes. This isn't possible in the first chapters, but the JET X stages that unlock in the final chapter do give you the space to play around. I didn't try the second loop of the game to see if you can actually select a stage freely or if you're stuck going through each one-by-one. 

[h1]Verdict - 5/5[/h1]
It's kind of funny to play this so long after [i]Sonic Adventure 2[/i]. I know there were months between both games' releases, but I wonder how much influence this had on the latter's development. Considering the presence of grinding rails, the different stage ranks that weren't present in the first [i]Sonic Adventure[/i], and Shadow skates... I don't know, awfully strange coincidences if that's all these are. That grind rails and ranks have been a [i]Sonic[/i] staple since is just serendipity, huh? 

That said, this game was a real treat. If I didn't have a dumb smile on my face, I had the 'try to do your best' tongue on upper lip look plastered on there instead. It was a good challenge, but still really fun to play, and the funky beats definitely were a highlight for me. I'm not the kind of person to chase high scores, so I'm probably done with the game, but I'm definitely glad this one popped up on my radar.

125017421.review:
Jet Set Radio Is an absolute blast of a game with fun game play, a fun story, fun music, Great Graphics and fun challenges. 
For a game that released In 2000 the graphics still hold up great especially In 4k quality. Its cel shaded style Is great. The story basically Involves you In this youth gang who goes around spraying graffiti around Tokyo for claiming your turf or going up against other youth gangs. The cutscenes are wacky and fun and are entertaining to watch.
The games style Is very of Its time with Its art direction and soundtrack having a very late 90s early 2000s feel to It but In 2022 all of that still holds up great as I love Its Art style and the soundtrack Is good to give the game an extra fun energy to It which makes the levels more fun. 
Speaking of the levels they are very well designed. There's only 5 areas but as you progress the same few areas get more expansive and big which makes them fun to explore later on In the game. In these places the game will assign you to rather spray paint onto other rival gangs members, Race other people who will join your group after beating them in a race, Spray at random parts of the places to claim to other gangs that this turf is yours and there Is also some missions where you try get as many points as you can before timer runs out. 
The points one Is none story related but still a fun challenge to do. The character selections Is quite big in this game. Depending who you pick they control the same In terms of there movements but some can get more spray paint cans than others and some might have a higher health bar and some might have different combos when your spraying graffiti.
 I think all the characters are very well designed and stand out. I usually like playing as Beat, Mew and Combo. I Especially recommend playing as Combo when you unlock him as his health bar is massive. 
This game has a bit of a learning curve to It but once you understand how the game plays It is really fun to grind and skate around these levels spraying graffiti and doing the characters different combos with spraying on your left stick (If being played by an Xbox or Playstation controller like me). 
The game offers fun replay factor with trying to get high ranks on each level which I trying to do. 
Each area Is so memorable I sometimes even just going around the levels and explore them cause Its so enjoyable.
Overall This game is high up there In my list of favorite games. The game play, graphics, style + everything else I love. High recommendation on this Sega Dreamcast classic.

As a huge jet set radio fan this is a good enough port, the bonuses are cool and the changes such as widescreen etc are nice however just a few of them i dislike such as the map being moved in the menu. However when I first tried to play JSR on steam i had LOADS of issues, initially i couldn't get the game to open at all and it turns out the steam shortcut was crashing it for some reason. I also couldn't use my controller and i have no clue what fixed that. other than those issues i had when first trying to play the game its been pretty much smooth sailing apart from a few crashes.

The game itself is absolutely amazing, its hands down one of my favourite games of all time and has a really nice mix of difficulty yet accessibility to casual players. The visual artstyle is shockingly amazing ESPECIALLY considering this game came out in the year 2000 and still looks good. Ontop of this the music is absolutely sublime, the game would be outright incomplete without it. Hideki naganuma and everyone else did an amazing job adding style and character to the world and manages to stand on its own without the context of the game (although not always). As for the gameplay its great, some people call it clunky but i have no clue how that'd be the case unless you're just really bad at it because i find it to be smooth. Other than that tangent it's incredibly fun and satisfying.

TLDR: its really good and absolutely worth the price
Ps: Works great on deck !
Jet set radio future port please :)

122789499.review:
I'm still slightly unsure about not recommending this game, but I feel like I need to because the experience is truly not fun in many places. While watching the game's documentary in the bonus section, I felt for how much the creators loved this game and wanted to make something fun. Unfortunately, they were dealing with the system capabilities of their time. This is probably one of those perfect examples of a retro game beloved by its fans and probably amazing for its time, but which doesn't hold up. I would even admit this is a gem worth trying if you can live with the flaws and difficulties. Try it if you like this kind of thing or want to experience something that probably influenced a whole lot of people … but otherwise, I can't recommend this game for most people.

Starting on the positives, there's a decent sense of accomplishment for getting all the achievements, which extends this pretty short game to an acceptable length. Though the Detached achievement is super frustrating for how you can't know until the end if you did everything right. I like the dance party menu and the interesting group of icon characters, and there's also a lot of neat levels with more connections and paths between areas than you might realize, like the subway platforms or leaving the downhill area from the bottom. Though the super-vertical Grind Square is painful every time you fall and actually kind of lame once you realize how the infinite grind loop works.

Well that was fun listing all the positives. My struggle to enjoy this game came from how frustrating and imprecise the controls were. Perhaps that was partly on me for using keyboard controls, but there were awkward moments that a controller wouldn't have helped. For example, racing against others is extremely annoying because just bumping into someone will send you skating off in the opposite direction no matter how much your character weighs. The designers knew this made racing almost impossible because they actually have the NPC stop and wait for you at the half-way point. Only the last half actually matters, and your real opponent for getting high ratings is the clock.

There's a bunch of characters to select from, but I'm not sure if any of them actually skate differently in this skating game? Big characters feel slower, but they can win races too. Some characters seem to jump higher, but not consistently. A section on How To Skate buried in the options will tell you that a character's stats are for how many points they get when doing either skate tricks or graffiti, but the latter doesn't change how the art looks to you. They also say that characters who are good at graffiti will carry less paint, which basically increases the challenge for those speed-focused runs, but then you can unlock characters with great graffiti scores and big paint storage.

The tutorial teaches you things you will never need to use like skating backwards (which is almost impossible with keyboard controls) then does a terrible job teaching important things like wall riding (they tell you to run at a wall, but not that only certain walls actually work for this) and then require you to figure out the essentials of infinite grind loops from there. The in-story “follow my example” challenges were way better at teaching essential concepts, yet that challenge type is criminally underutilized and maybe should have been much more central to the game. I was actually happy when unlocking Pots involved a tough one.

I don't like some of the sound design choices they made in this very sound-inspired game. Some music is fine (I was reminded of the far better The World Ends With You, Gameboy version) but I wanted to keep the music as low as possible because every track in the game is a loop that gets annoying fast and they fail to keep a variety going. There's even some music in the bonus section and radio player that doesn't play during story missions? Also you can't fine-tune the volume, there's just one slider that only goes down to 50%. I get them wanting to have their music blasting, but why not give me control too? And characters constantly shout the most annoying catchphrase lines over and over when they do things, so mostly I chose my character by who was least irritating.

Last and kind of least, the quarter pipes are bad, the final level sucks and I experienced a few game crashes in situations where maybe the game code was over-taxed. On the other hand, this game does get better after the initial frustrations wear off. For me, I started having some fun well after finishing the short main story and deep into my NewGame+ while chasing achievements, only after I understood what I was supposed to be doing and what mattered. That's basically the problem. A game should not take that long to get good. So unless you can stick around for that moment of zen, I would not recommend this retro gem.

It feels like I'm playing QWOP but with rollerskates. Everything is so sluggish and the direction of your jump feels so inconsistent and the momentum is all weird and it feels like your treading through a knee deep swamp. Part of this is likely from my bias towards JSRF as I grew up playing that game and I didn't know JSR existed until later in life, but I just enjoy everything about JSRF better. Atmosphere, art style, music, controls, maps. The only thing I can say about JSR that is better is the graffiti mechanic, but even then the input feels inconsistent with some of the inputs. If you just want a game for the experience and the atmosphere, and the controls aren't a big deal to you, give this a try, it bleeds personality and it's a very unique game, you won't get another game like this with the exception of JSRF. But if your  like me and you can't handle a fundamental part of the like the controls, maybe watch a playthrough or try JSRFMP cuz we ain't getting a JSRF port anytime soon :/

120321381.review:
For the first hour or so of playing Jet Set Radio, I was fully considering dropping the game soon after. Fortunately I ended up sticking with it, because with a bit more time I finally started to see this as an absolutely fantastic little experience. At its core, JSR is also a game that felt as if it allowed me to better understand certain dichotomies between the game design approach between Nintendo and Sega and how they were able to cultivate a lot of experiences that felt remarkably distinct, each with their own pros and cons to them. While Nintendo tended to approach games largely from the perspective of having a player understand the majority of the game's systems immediately and intuitively to make for something inviting and accessible, Sega consistently seemed to more go for the approach of "Hey, the first few hours of this are going to suck but once it clicks it's the best stuff ever". This feels especially true for this game however, as getting into it proves to be a bit rough due to the control scheme feeling incredibly loose and difficult to handle, with a wide turn radius and a constant sense of momentum that means you can't immediately slow down making it really difficult to start off with as even the most simple obstacles feel like fighting against the game. However, with a bit of time, once you get used to it all, it becomes increasingly clear how so many of the mobility quirks that you have lend themselves perfectly to the level design.

For a movement system that practically requires the player to be getting a bit of a running start to properly gain momentum and actually reach a lot of higher locations, not to mention maintaining this speed for a pretty long time whether you want to or not since rollerskates just tend to do that, it needs to be complemented by level design that supports this, and here's where Jet Set Radio largely shines. Grind rails, secret areas and just your general avenues of traversal tend to be spaced out in such a way where you can flow naturally from one location to another as long as you have a general idea of where everything is. Jumps are spaced in such a way that you'll be finding yourself effortlessly perfectly positioning yourself to barely slow down after a while, it goes from something that feels like it's fighting against the player to something that feels incredibly intuitive, but then also satisfying due to the player knowing how much they had struggled at first to make even the most basic of manoeuvres. It all contributes to a feeling that the game is less interested in seeing you merely beat the stages, and instead wants you to absolutely master them.

This idea of mastery continues to be represented through the way that the enemies within the game are handled, initially seeming like pointless distractions that serve to frustrate and slow you down, but actually being utilised as a clever way to further force the player to understand the levels and plan their routes carefully from the start. Because the intensification of enemy waves is based exclusively off of how many spots you've tagged without the time taken having any bearing, planning is a far more important step to the game than it first lets on, to the point where once you figure out how to approach getting around a stage, the pacing can often feel rather leisurely, with even the most intense waves still being easily managed due to the remaining targets being simple to reach nonetheless. So many elements that initially seem like a hindrance to the Jet Set Radio's experience ultimately prove to contribute to the core gameplay loop in an incredibly organic way to the point where you'll often feel as if you're just being let loose without any real sense of overbearing guidance, even though the game is really nudging you in the right direction for the entire duration.

This reaches its peak with the rival battles thrown throughout the game, that either make you race against someone or just follow what they do, which doesn't only often lead to you being taught about certain tricks to make getting around easier, one example being sliding across walls for extra height, but you'll often be taught about little shortcuts as well. These end up feeling exciting not only because you're being taught about so many things that were always there that you probably just didn't know about, but it all links back into making replaying those stages later all the more satisfying as you once again get to entirely redefine your route with these new tricks and passages in mind, feeding into the remarkable replayability that the game has. Of course, despite all of this, it's still hard to deny that the best aspect of the game for me is just how much insane style it has to it, with the colourful, cel - shaded art making every area be filled to the seams with so much charm, bringing life to what could've potentially been a dreary urban sprawl. The art is further complemented by Hideki Naganuma's amazing soundtrack that takes a lot of cues from instrumental hip hop and the big beat scene to make for one of the coolest OSTs to a game out there, with even the occasional lulls in quality still carrying such a strong vibe to carry the game's aesthetic up into the stratosphere.

On the whole, while I cannot fault anyone who plays this game and hates it for the way you control your character, it not only is a system that progressively feels better the more you play, but the design of the levels and encounters themselves is absolutely incredible in how it perfectly balances between knocking the player around and silently guiding them into feeling like they're pulling off some absolutely insane stunts. While I already love the game, it's also another case where it almost feels built to be replayed a bunch, and those small annoying moments that appear from time to time are nowhere near enough to tank the experience by very much. Definitely worth a shot especially if you love its aesthetic, and even if you've played it and didn't like it very much, honestly give it another small shot, you might be pleasantly surprised.

8/10

jet set radio is a classic 3D platformer from sega that originally released on the sega dreamcast in the year 2000. the main story has strong anti-establishment themes, as you play as a gang member in tokyo spraying graffiti on everything. the game is most widely known for it's eccentric and unique soundtrack, as well as the fact that the developer team was small and extremely young (average age of the entire dev team was under 25 years old). there's decent replayability as well, 100%'ing this game was a thoroughly enjoyable experience. this game is a steal when bundled in the sega dreamcast collection on steam, getting all the dreamcast games to get a steam port is such a great value and i can't recommend that package enough.

117949101.review:
This game is simply amazing in every way: the art style is beautiful and it really helps the game remain timeless; the music is always a joy to listen to; Hideki Naganuma is a musical genius (it's sad that he parted ways with Sega, but they didn't really have the best relationship anyways). The story is so over the top that I can't help but laugh.

The only problems I really have with this game, and I'm not even sure if it's the game or if it's this port, are that the controls are extremely janky, along with the camera being really inconsistent at times. along with the ridiculous achievements. But I can live with these things; this game is simply too much fun to let them detract from my experience.

My biggest question is: where is Jet Set Radio Future? That game improves upon every aspect of this game and is overall a more polished experience. I doubt we'll ever get it on Steam (seeing as it's been 10 years since this port was brought to Steam), but I don't want to give up hope. But if it never comes, at least we have Bomb Rush Cyberfunk coming out soon.

But I digress; please play this game if you have never played it before, or if you have played it before, play it again!

Jet Set Radio holds up surprisingly well 22 years later.

The general aesthetic and style this game has oozes on to you in the title screen alone. Exploring Tokyo-to, Bantam Street, and Grind Square was always fun albeit frustrating at times.

This being a 22 year old game the general controls for movement and spray painting are what you'd expect, nothing too clunky or annoying, I definitely can *not*  say the same thing about the camera system though, chunkiness levels are through the roof with it where it goes all over the damn place when accessing small areas such as a tunnel or small alleyway. But it being a 22 year old game I sort of expected that and just learned to deal with it.

If you're going into Jet Set Radio expecting a fun nostalgic time, go for it, fully delivers on that front. Even if you're not the nostalgic type or is your first time playing it, I still recommend it because overall it's a fantastic game and has cemented itself as a pop culture icon of it's time.

116226213.review:
Great music, great colors, great art style. For its time, this is a classic. [b][i]There is, without any doubt, fun and nostalgia to be had[/i][/b]—I played to full completion of the story, plus some miscellaneous challenges/activities that offered further replayability.

Unfortunately, the gameplay fails to hold up under modern scrutiny, and as such I cannot recommend this game to the [i]majority[/i] of potential players.

[h1]Technical Issues[/h1]
This game is an old port. Be prepared for the possibility that you may need to [b](1)[/b] launch in compatibility mode, [b](2)[/b] download old redistributables not packaged with the game, and/or [b](3)[/b] jump through other small hoops to get the game to boot properly.

I first tried playing a couple years ago, but critical assets (characters, scenes...) would not load properly. I gave up and tried again more recently, and only experienced a few (2–4) hard crashes.

[h1]Controller vs. K&M[/h1]
The debate over which is better isn't relevant. I played with both, across multiple missions of varying difficulty, and even switched mid-mission at times to see if a certain sequence of movements would be easier. You'll get used to the default control mapping, and you will encounter the same problems with scuffed movement and camera woes. Ultimately, I decided that keyboard and mouse felt a little bit better.

If you truly must, you can remap your controls. Although, there is an accursed "multi-purpose" button, and you cannot separate the two wildly different actions assigned to it.

[h1]Gameplay Thoughts[/h1]
[h2]The Camera[/h2]
In narrow areas, or anywhere where your back is against a wall, the camera angles itself poorly. Clipping, being pushed above or below... even as you rotate it manually, the camera is likely to get stuck. Effectively, sometimes you just [b][i]don't have control[/i][/b] over your own camera.

There is a "reset camera" button, but it's not useful. Even in those problematic areas, all the "reset camera" button does is spasm about for a couple seconds, and then return to its unhelpful state. I'd recommend not using this feature, but it's mapped to the same button used for spraying graffiti—[b]the most important action in the game[/b].

Chase missions highlight this flaw best, but any mission that involves spraying graffiti within a narrow timing window is rough. For chase missions in particular, you need to graffiti the back of a moving target multiple times. The ideal strategy is to spam the graffiti button when you're directly behind the target. However – the position you have to be in is precise, you move slightly faster than the target, touching the target will stun you, and you need to follow the target through turns and grinds.

The result is that you can't see anything. As you tailgate the target, you [i]frequently[/i] lose and regain the ability to graffiti multiple times each second. Thus, your camera will constantly be swinging around wildly.

[h2]Freedom of Movement[/h2]
Jet Set Radio's gameplay solely hinges on the concept of movement. Unfortunately, it fails to provide you with responsive movement. When movement works, it feels great. There is a genuine mastery you can gain over the system, even with its flaws. But when it doesn't work, it feels needlessly cheap, and greatly discouraging. So for this to be the game's biggest flaw,—this is incredibly disappointing.

My biggest gripes stem from rails refusing to cooperate. Try to skate on, but you slide off. Try to jump on, but the game pushes you away and you miss the rail by a hair's width. Land the rail without momentum, and now you're forced to slowly hop across the rail to move forward.

You can't immediately jump off the rail to try again either. Without momentum, you're unable to propel yourself far enough to not get magnetized back on. So you must hop forward a few times to build momentum, then jump perpendicularly to get far enough away from the rail to disconnect from it.

[h2]Level Design and Enemies[/h2]
On a higher note, the level design is fun. The locations are stand-out, and aesthetically interesting. I complain about the grinding, but the rails and walls are cleverly placed throughout the map to make it possible for really cool tricks to be performed once you hit a higher level of mastery. Some of the final missions even take you across all of a location's sub-areas, which is really cool.

In many ways, the only real downside of the level design is that it doesn't feel like the enemies were designed for the maps they've been placed in. They succeed in being a hazard, but they're not fun and many lack meaningful counterplay (despite being placed in large quantities).

Tear gas doesn't pay respect to the rhythm of the game, so it can just interrupt your movement if it gets queued up at a bad time. Tanks are interesting, but having ten of them with machine guns feels silly and needlessly punishing when the tank cannon already exists. The difficulty build-up to attack helicopters makes sense and they feel fine to play against, but the maps they're placed on don't feel designed for them. Some of the more static enemies are placed next to a medium or large graffiti, and the best "counterplay" is to just face-tank the damage for the i-frames.

The final mission (and final boss) is also quite weird. It utilizes basically none of the elements the game teaches you up to that point, and the level design feels hollow. There's no real sense of accomplishment in completing this mission for me, and the build-up to it was far better than the final mission itself.

[h2]Story and Characters[/h2]
Realistically, you're not playing for the story. Although it's a shame that Captain Onishima is an infinitely more interesting character than the actual villain, and yet he just [i]exits the story[/i] with such little acknowledgement. Regardless, all the character designs are still unique and interesting.

[h1]In Conclusion...[/h1]
If you're just wanting to hit up an old classic for some good music and nostalgia, go for it. But if you're looking to revisit the gameplay, I strongly recommend against it. There are more modern games that do it better.

114257331.review:
A game I loved 20 years ago, and wanted to see if it held up.  Suprise, it still does.  I'd say it's better now, seeing as how an hour flies by when playing. The QoL changes and extras, along with short load times, really help this package for someone looking for 3D platformer they might not know they wanted, but are glad they stumbled across.    The games approach to grind lines that act as a 'traditional' platforms in other games, on top of scoring and gaining speed.  

The controls are still the same as I remember them, except I'm playing on a Dual Shock 4 instead of the DC controller, and they feel tighter as a result.  The right stick camera control is  a nice addition.

How it handles grinding is still a talking point as it was upon it's release.  It's not always initially known what is and isn't grind-able or wall ride-able and even then it could come down to the angle you come from.  There are some spots that require you to experiment that you would think to work easy enough.  Once you get those down the game will reward you and you'll find a game is extremely rewarding to navigate in style through on multiple runs, like any good game.

Graphics and presentation are still top-notch after all these years.  The dense hills and cities of Neo-Tokyo and even the U.S. added stages still look gorgeous especially night.  The varied terrain and  various ways to get around are still a blast to navigate.  

If you're looking for a 3D platformer cut from a different cloth, this is one that is still worth your attention.

110591439.review:
It's a classic, while it is it a bit on the jank side (like most dreamcast games) it's very memorable and the music is just incredible. It's got so much personality and charm to it, it really is unforgettable. Jet Set Radio drops you into a level and your only goal is to spray paint all the set locations on the map under the time limit (usually 10-15 mins). You're free to do them in any order using whatever character you like, each one has different stats and aesthetics and you unlock more as you go along. 

I think the worst thing about this game is probably the difficulty spikes, this game has some really lousy missions here and there that require trial and error/knowing exactly where and how to get to certain graffiti spots. A lot of the struggles you'll have with this game are due to the controls, you feel very heavy and it takes a bit to gain momentum and you can lose it in an instant. I definitely think the sequel to this game does a better job and is a better game overall, it's a shame there's no way to play that one unless you have an original Xbox though.

Nevertheless I definitely recommend trying this one out, it's one of the most iconic games on the Dreamcast and I still find it fun to play even now, or if just listen to the soundtrack instead that works too.

108858672.review:
while it may be dated in terms of movement controls and graphics since it was for the dreamcast.
Jet Set Radio has the style, energy and gameplay that, while simple, is very fun once you get  use to the slight jank from the movement.

there are many characters to unlock, including the enemies that you face once you beat the game, speaking of that, once you do you can load up your finished save and start from the begining with all your unlocked crew.

levels start out as small isolated areas but eventually you find out as you progress that the 3 area's of each of the 3 levels interconnect, now you might not be able to make one big combo is most of these interconnected levels, save one, the noise tanks territory, if you do it right.

speaking of combos, those are mostly just grinds, you automatically stick to anything you can grind and when you build enough speed and jump you do long distance flips these are how you chain grinds together, no tricks while grinding though but each point gain is considered a trick so long grinds are good for that.

all in all, the story goes from zero to 100 pretty quick, starting out as a 3 man gang, having the police shoot at you for skating and spray painting, to eventually the military coming after you because......they hate graffiti? anyway i recommend this a lot.

108355549.review: I can't really say much that hasn't already been said about Jet Set Radio, but I'll talk about it anyway. This game is extremely stylish, using the limitations of the Dreamcast, the console it originally released to, to create a unique art style that doesn't sacrifice processing power and take away from the gameplay. The controls can feel a bit stiff sometimes, which can admittedly lead to some frustration. Plus, the way to unlock extra characters can be a bit tedious or pose a tough challenge to casual players, such as myself. All that being said, the game looks great. the cartoony, cell-shaded art style of the characters and the various, sprawling maps packaged with the funky rap beats and remixes make a wonderful, stylish experience that doesn't drag on for too long and leaves you satisfied, but somehow still wanting more.

108186514.review:
Controller is more than recommended, if not required.

This game plays like a more accesible Tony Hawk, with automatic air tricks and grinds. 
The levels are GREAT, dense and with many interconnected zones, they really feel like cities. You can pull of great combos and air with enough skill, which is mostly getting your character to land on the right spots.

Where the game really shines though, STYLE. The characters, cel-shaded graphics and sountrack mesh perfectly. To me it is the perfect game to just vibe and play trying to make cool combos and reach Jet ranking in style.

The story is short, you can beat in in less than 2 hours if you know what you're doing.

The game is cheap, a bang for your buck, and worth a try.

108068371.review: this is one of those games that you had to play when it was launched. it was simply mind blowing then, in almost every way. who knew mixing skating and graffiti in japan could be such an amazing combo. this was actually one of the first games to use cel shading and it works so well here. the worlds feels very lived in, full of detail, amazing pedestrians with their own characteristics, cars, and so much charm capturing the 90s era so well. the character designs are also exceptional, each very iconic and despite not having much dialogue, you can still get a sense of who they might be. and of course the music, one of the best soundtracks of all time. the gameplay is definitely challenging at time, especially due to controls but you didnt care at the time because this was an incredible game. after 20 years im amazed at how well this game holds up and just how fun it still is to play.

107521292.review:
The most important bit of advice I'd give someone new to the game is to use character selection to modify the difficulty to your liking.
I found the game pretty difficult, frustrating at times, and given the low percentage of players who finished the story, I'd guess I'm not the only one. Picking a character with high power (health) and low graffiti (graffiti takes less time and you can carry more cans) made it far easier to enjoy my time with the game. Though characters with higher graffiti are an option for chasing high scores.

With its distinct visual style and fantastic soundtrack, there's plenty to love about the game. Certainly the soundtrack was at least half the reason for my interest.
Not knowing much about the game other than the music, aesthetic and a recommendation, I was pleasantly surprised by the politics of police brutality and villainous corporations. Then there's the ridiculous escalation with villains sending tanks and helicopters after graffiti-artist teens. It took me a while before I accidentally discovered that it's possible to take down helicopters by spraying graffiti on them. Glorious! A quiet, grounded game this is not. XP
Knowing that you can take down helicopters and some tougher enemies with graffiti is also helpful for harder levels, though I did realise on reflection that the game was trying to teach me that during the graffiti-gang-wars section where you chase down rivals to graffiti their backs until they surrender.

Pretty regularly a challenger appears at your window, and you complete their challenge to unlock them. Usually this consists of pulling off the tricks they demonstrate to you, but occasionally there's a race. One pair of character unlocks is tied to story progression and therefore not optional like the other challengers. Though if you try to ignore a challenger you'll get a reminder each time you're back at mission selection. I feel mixed about these personally. I dislike the races and the one tied to story progression took me a while. Whilst trick challenges were really satisfying to complete. A bit of soulsborne you-will-likely-fail-several-times zen is a good mindset to bring.

So yeah, if the look and sound of Jet Set Radio tickle your fancy, consider getting it on sale, brace yourself for the bumps in the road, and enjoy the wild ride and the energetic voice of our DJ Professor K.
