106384877.review:
The main complaint I see about this game are the physics, which I suppose is fair, but once you get accustomed to them you will be in for a groovy time. If you find yourself hating how this game controls, here is a tip: controlling your speed and maintaining momentum is everything. That, and understanding exactly how much your directional inputs effect your jumps off of rails, are all you really need to get a feel for. If you can pass the tutorial, then you'll start to get it.

Some clear oversights are present that Sega could address if they put in a bit more effort. Off the top of my head: 
 - Stage selection from the stage score menu would be ideal for grinding Jet ratings. Having to play through the whole game just to play through a story stage you already completed is inconvenient. 
 - Music from Jet Set Radio Future being unlockable is great and all, but it is only accessible in an extras menu with there being no option to use it in-game, which is just a waste. 
 - No "retry" option in the pause menu; you have to go back to the Garage and then reselect a stage to try again which is also inconvenient.
 - With all of the characters unlocked, I have to scroll through SEVEN other characters before I can select Gum and that is a [b]PROBLEM[/b].

I really didn't think I would play this game as much as I have. I thought I would beat it, then beat JSRF, then be satisfied until Bomb Rush Cyberfunk releases. But after I finished JSRF, days passed, but I wasn't quite ready to move on. It seems I am unable to resist my primal human urges to grind rails and disrespect authority to a funky beat, so I'm probably just going to keep playing this game until I 100% it.

TL;DR rock that shit homie

106189825.review: This is quite possibly one of the most fun games I have played in recent years. Jet Set Radio (or jet grind radio if you will) is a game similar to Tony Hawk Pro Skater. You do tricks and you have a time limit, but what makes this game stand out is your mission isn't to collect tapes or get a sick score, rather to cover up other people's graffiti. The characters are some of the most unique people I have seen in a video game. There's Beat, who ran away from home and is known to be a trouble maker. There is slate who has a big nose like squidward and can carry so many spray paint cans. Then there is my favorite, cube. Nothing too special about her, I just think goth girls are cool. The tricks in this game are a bit harder to pull off than pro skater, you can't just mash buttons and get an insane combo. You usually have to start grinding, build up some speed, and then jump to do a trick. This works out just fine, in my opinion. The story itself is interesting for a roller skating game. Basically there are gangs/groups of people that like to spray paint all over tokyo. Your group, The GG's, has one goal. To lay down some phat lines on other people's graffiti, while being chased by the cops. There are a couple of twists here and there that keep the story interesting. The music is literally the best video game music I have heard in recent years. Most of it is by Hideki Naganuma and I feel like it fits the tone of the game. In the USA version, we got some real sweet metal tracks. Dragula by rob zombie and just got wicked by cold, which are my personal favorites. Overall, this game is amazing. Great gameplay and a amazing soundtrack.  I highly recommend this.

105800276.review:
Oh boy, where do I start...

Jet Set Radio is unlike any other game I have seen before and I wish I had played it sooner! I've been putting it off because I though it would be like GTA which isn't my type of game.

The style of this game is iconic. Hideki Naganuma is definitely one of my favourite video game music producers and I would consider JSR's soundtrack to be one of my all time favourite video game soundtracks of all time. If you're not intending to buy the game, you should AT LEAST listen to the soundtrack. The art style is timeless, the use of cel shading makes the game look good even by today's standards. 

The game generally controls well, although it can be a bit clunky at times, however I would recommend playing this game with a controller. I played this game with my keyboard because I'm poor, and when it came to graffiting I could only play as characters who had less complicated moves. So, please, PLEASE play this game with a controller for the definitive experience. 

As for the plot it's thrown so many curveballs at me in it's insane! One of the best parts of this game, in my humble opinion, is seeing how brutal the police gets with their attempts in stopping you. From tanks, to tear gas, you name it! Not to mention the ending, which I will obviously not spoil, after finishing the game I was in such a state of shock that I had begun taking yoga classes. It's not shocking in the sense that it is horrifying or traumatic, it's just REALLY bizarre and I didn't know how to process it. 

However, I would DEFINITELY recommend this game, it's such a great experience that no other game could ever replicate (well ignoring Bomb Rush Cyberfunk). 

Now SEGA, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD PLEASE PORT JET SET RADIO FUTURE TO STEAM! I wanna play it so bad, not to mention many other titles of yours...

105794299.review:
An artistic gem lost to the sands of time due to a mix of unfortunate circumstances surrounding the console it was put on, and its lack of relevancy to its domestic market. It's absolutely worth experiencing.

Graphics:

Maybe it's pointless to talk about graphics for a game that released over 2 decades ago, but Jet Set Radio practically pioneered cel-shading in gaming. The game's bright color-palette and comic-like appearance gives it a distinct style that ages well compared to other games from its time.

Soundtrack:

Need I elaborate? It's probably the reason you're even interested in this game. Let's look at the funk!
Hideki Naganuma is a name that gets thrown around, and without a doubt his are some of the most iconic and recognized tracks. There are other artists who've contributed tracks to this game. in addition to Hideki Naganuma's distinct sample-infused funk, you'll also encounter tracks from other similar DJs such as Richard Jacques, Castle Logical, Deavid Soul, and Toronto. Hilariously, the game even features a song that directly references and glorifies the Super Mario Brothers, sung by Guitar Vader.

Gameplay:

This is something not many people elaborate on... but it should definitely be talked about. Jet Set Radio was developed by a young, passionate, and inexperienced team. So whilst all the game's ideas are implemented in earnesty and in fun... they do not mesh together well.

The elements will be examined separately.

The trick system: Jet Set Radio's grinding system is serviceable, but is highly based on the momentum you have when starting the grind. Navigating upwards is often difficult and requires planning and time. Tricks are performed automatically as you grind, and also when jumping whilst going a certain speed, or when jumping off a wallride. Learning how and where to chain these tricks together is both satisfying and rewarding. The one thing you really need to be wary of however, is that any direction held on the thumbstick will cause you to jump sharply in that direction. When it is intended it works great. When you think you're holding forward and you veer off to the right... it can be a problem. Halfpipe jumps while not very important to the gameplay loop, nevertheless aren't always pulled off when you expect them to be.

The graffiti system: The central objective of Jet Set Radio is to spray graffiti tags on various surfaces throughout a level. For medium and large tags, this is done through stand-still quick time events. While the QTE's themselves are fun to pull off... the length of vulnerability you suffer from attempting them is at best stress-inducing, and at worst makes it impossible to finish a tag 'cleanly' in some positions.

Enemies: The enemies in Jet Set Radio have very creative visual design, but do not play nice with the graffiti system. Some large tags, (some of which require 7 seperate QTE sequences to be done in a row for max points!) Lie in areas that enemies either guard or patrol... and most of the enemies are completely invincible and cannot be distracted from the spots you need to tag long enough for it to be safe. The only thing you can do to prevent from dealing with this issue is strategically selecting the order in which you do tags... but even so, some of the levels in the third chapter forbid this technique entirely.

Conclusion: Jet Set Radio is a beautiful work of art. But its gameplay loop makes it hard to play 'cleanly'. The game's challenges mainly comes from design choices that do not harmonize well with each other. This being said, Jet Set Radio as an *idea* for a franchise is utterly remarkable, and stands as a cult classic due to its criminally untapped potential.

101146541.review:
Jet Set Radio is a classic. There is no other way to describe it. Playing it takes me right back to the 2000s. 
When it comes to video games, there are four important factors that I use to determine whether I like a game or not. These are:

- Story (If applicable)
- Gameplay
- Graphics
- Music

Jet Set Radio has an alright story in my opinion. When it comes to gameplay, the controls on the PC are a bit confusing in terms of spraying graffiti which is a mandatory action within the game. It took me a while to figure out how to perform the more complicated directions which involves tapping numerous keys at the same time. I also figured out TODAY that you could skate backwards. I love the graphics. The cel-shading is really good for the time it was made in and the character designs are really unique. My personal favourite is the design for the Love Shockers. I also love the fact you can create your own graffiti. The music is epic. I mean epic. Certain tracks are really memorable like Humming The Bassline, Let Mom Sleep, That's Enough and Improvise. The style of music really fits with the game in my opinion. 

I do however have one issue. There needs to be a JSRF port for PC.

99879748.review:
[h1]A fantastic classic.[/h1]
Still holds up, though some of the mechanics aged like fine milk.

[h1]Lets start with the positives:[/h1]
+ The Cell-shaded look still holds up, the improved resolution and Anti-aliasing play big part in that. Not much in terms of effects and particles, but overall the game is pleasant to look at and quite distinct.
+ The soundtrack is fantastic. Hideki Naganuma (ignore his reddit-tier twitter) is a fantastic musician and his work in this game is some great stuff (check out his other stuff in Sonic Rush and Lethal League, its worth it). There is also a number of other musicians participating, overall the soundtrack is stellar. 
+ The controls let you do some really fun things once you get used to them. Skating and chaining combos while avoiding Rokkaku/Police leads to some really thrilling gameplay which all comes thanks to your skill, no handholding at all.
+ A lot of characters to choose from letting you pick a character that feels the best for you.

[h1]Now for the bad things:[/h1]
- Controls while fine once you get used to them are really, how should i put it, stiff. You are on rollerblades, which is fair enough, but things like jumping from rail to rail require a lot of practice, since the stick influences the direction of your jump [i] really [/i] hard
- The difficulty curve. You would be hard pressed to find a game that requires you to adapt and learn this quickly as Jet Set Radio. You do the first couple of "tutorial" challenges, then you do the first level. Everything is normal. Then you start doing levels in any order you want. But whats that, a rival fight? You can recruit more characters, so why not give it a try. These are noticably more difficult, but you can do it with enough trial and error. Then you get to chapter 2 after like 2 hours of gameplay, and you are thrown into some really difficult stuff, like the race against Beat as Combo, which you are not winning on your first couple of tries. The last chases against gang members where you have to tag them are brutal as well, requiring you to keep trying and brute forcing it. Controls dont help, as the stiffness makes you feel like a snail compared to the on-rails AI which does all these crazy tricks while you desperately try to keep up. You will manage eventually, but the path to beating the game is not an easy one. 
- Tutorial is an optional thing in the menu, but its more difficult than around 80% of the actual game. Trying to chain 50 tricks together at the end of it is not something you can expect someone who just bought the game to do in a reasonable amount of time (under 2 hours). Ive been playing this game on dreamcast and i still find that difficult. 
- Unlocking the extra characters is a chore. Getting the JET rating on every level in the game is much more difficult task than it should be. And you unlock a bunch of them at once, so there isnt even a sense of progression. 
- Some of the achievements sound so painful to do i dont even wanna attempt them, despite being an achievement whorj myself. Not getting latched onto or using every graffiti? Really game?


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

A fantastic game definitely worth your time. Its not a walk in the park and it will test your resolve in trying to get through it, but the punishment for mistakes is not that big, at worst its a restart of a level which can all be completed relatively quickly once you know the layout. Music is amazing, the looks still hold up. A definite classic you should get, and its on sale pretty often. Here's hoping for a JSRF release someday.

99193144.review:
This game is very good but has aged not so well. I'd like to clear up that I love this game and think the art and everything on the visual and auditory side are great. This soundtrack in someways even eclipses the sequel which is also great. If you don't know about any of this then you will undoubtedly have a blast experiencing it for the first time.

With that acknowledged I feel I must admit that the gameplay for this game can be very hit or miss. Rail grinding and tagging walls is fun but there are constantly things interrupting the flow of whatever line you may be doing. Running up stairs, getting weird collision with the level that stops all your momentum, the game not letting you land on a rail that you should've... There are a lot of things that would make me describe the movement in this game as super floaty. Generally, you would be surprised how difficult it can be to maneuver in this game. I think that for a game pretty much entirely about tricks and movement, this one falls short in many departments especially as you start to get into the later levels which are lot more tight and punishing. It hurts me to level this much criticism on this game but I genuinely think that the movement is super unpolished and for a game of this kind its outmatched (in this department) by its contemporaries like Tony Hawk Pro Skater 2. At the end of the day though this remake is extremely cheap and I feel that with the price in mind there is a lot more to be gained than lost here.

If you want to try Jet Set Radio, there is no reason why my criticisms should stop you. If anything, I recommend you go play it because of how significant it is to not only video games but art as a whole. This is still one of my favorite games I just wish the movement was a little better. So if you are going to get the game keep that in mind.

99053069.review:
Pros:

- The first game ever to utilize cel-shaded graphics to my knowledge. The art style holds up 21 years later.

- Iconic soundtrack. Though limited in quantity compared to something like Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 1+2, the soundtrack covers any genre you could possibly associate with urban graffiti and pulls it off almost universally across the board. I'm not sure if you can customize the soundtrack but I just never saw any need to do so because everything is at [i]least[/i] good, at there are a handful of songs and tracks that absolutely propel this game into the stratosphere of legendary video game OSTs (with some licensed songs that do their part perfectly, and in [i]Improvise[/i]'s case, steals the show).

- Impossibly fun. The skating mechanics are far more simplistic than something like Tony Hawk but they work perfectly, since most of the time the grinds you pull off are secondary to painting walls with stunning graffiti art. The stylized graphics of cel-shading were the only way this could be achieved, and with Jet Set Radio, the marriage of style and art melded so perfectly that the most famous and highly regarded imitator ended up being Nintendo with [i]The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker[/i], which just so happens to be another of my favorite games and is bar none the most beautiful Zelda game to date. The style holds up so well I'm disappointed that it largely isn't seen much anymore. We can chalk that up to a bunch of cel-shaded imitators not being very good games I guess.

- The time limit associated with each level you play makes it feel very much like Tony Hawk, and it plays very much like an extended but simple version of it in modes were trick score constitutes the bulk of your points. I should clarify that it's simple but never too simple, and the grinds you're capable of put the blobs of goo in Tony Hawk to shame. Pulling off huge grinds is never not satisfying and it makes anything you do in this game a joy to play, combined with covering the streets with fantastic artwork and making your pursuers look silly in the process.

- The scoring operates on a scale which goes in order from bottom to top: Pedal, Motor, Engine, Turbo, Nitro, and Jet. Increasing your score unlocks new fun things like hidden characters, giving you tangible incentive besides achievements to continue playing and improving.

- The main narrative of this game is as stylized as the artwork, but it's incredibly short even for its day. People used to modern games might be underwhelmed with what the game has to offer at first, but like the underrated [i]Luigi's Mansion[/i], it pays off to replay the game and discover new ways to make the levels infinitely enjoyable. It has bigger areas compared to Tony Hawk that contain interconnected zones, making the city you skate through feel surprisingly realistic. Few games even today can pull that off without just throwing the entire city into the game. The urban feeling present here is palpable.

- I love every character in the game. Cube is my favorite, followed by Gum. Each of them have stats that indicate how much health they have, how much they score off grinds, and how much they score off graffiti (and how tricky it is to pull graffiti off). These stats are labeled in-game as Power, Technique, and Graffiti, and are a clue as to which characters you should use in which modes. Each character also can hold a certain max amount of spray paint cans, which you collect in each level to paint graffiti, further adding or subtracting challenge and nuance.

- Despite being older, it works well on my modern PC. I don't remember it crashing, and there's only the odd and rare sound glitch you'll need to tolerate. I run an AMD system on Windows 10 Home with a 2080 Super. Full controller support is included to my knowledge. I use a wired Xbox One controller.

CONS:

- Quality of life components universally present in modern games don't exist in this one. The inability to restart the level you're playing from the pause menu without having to go back to the garage makes Jet Crush (a mode where you race AI characters to paint a certain area on the map) particularly annoying when you make a mistake that dooms you to lose. When that happens, all you can do is wait until your opponent gets to the end, which could be any number of seconds. The entertaining dance your character does if left idle is little compensation, and if I wasn't high all the time it might piss me off rather than just annoy me a little. You could also choose to go back to the garage, re-select the stage, and slowly scroll back to whatever character you were using just to try again, but that's not nearly as fun as having Gum sway and swing her arms to the beat for a few seconds.

- The game is short and there are only five levels + the inventive and unique boss level. There isn't a clunker in the bunch and all of them are multi-tiered either vertically or horizontally, but I won't say I wasn't disappointed when I technically beat the game in about five hours (and I play games slowly).

--
CONCLUSION:
This is a fantastic game, even today. Get it, play it, and get hype for Bomb Rush Cyberfunk.

how to fix the various game bugs:
1) rename and swap the two .exe files after eachother, to make it run properly in the steam window (jsrsetup and jetsetradio)

Recommend it BUT HUGE TECHNICAL ISSUES

Game wasn't launching for me so I had to google and found solution:

>Find your Jet Set Radio folder in the steam folder, for me it's C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Jet Set Radio

>Simply swap the names of the two .exe files around jsrsetup to jetsetradio and jetsetradio to jsrsetup and it will work when you launch the game!


So yeah, the game doesn't even launch properly. Also:

Can't turn off sound effects, can only turn off music

Tutorial to press right and left triggers aka L2 and R2 but really means L1 and R1

On the menu says to use right stick for camera, right stick does nothing, does not move camera

So why am I recommending it? Because the game's good. Cool and unique visuals and music. Plays pretty good, even if the controls are a bit floaty and imprecise 

Kind of ridiculous that these very very basic technical issues exist, considering the developer's only job was porting a pre-existing game and they screwed it up on such an obvious level

Lamentablemente no lo puedo recomendar, aunque me lo haya pasado. El juego tiene un control "de la era Dreamcast" en el sentido de que aún no estaba del todo pulido el control 3D y se nota sobre todo a la hora de saltar en el aire que tienes mucha rigidez en los giros, poca inercia, flotas mucho en el aire y las colisiones para hacer acrobacias no son precisas. Esto hace que tengas que aprender los defectos del control y adaptarte a ello para poder jugar, en especial cuando la cámara no está de tu parte.

Todos los personajes se manejan igual y solo se diferencian en la barra de vida que tienen, en cuantos botes de pintura pueden llevar y cuantos puntos dan sus grafittis. Las patrullas enemigas cuando quedan pocos grafitis por pintar en un nivel son casi invencibles y tienes que aprovecharte del parpadeo del daño para seguir pintando porque no hay forma de detenerlos salvo que te zafes de ellos a una cornisa por la que no te puedan seguir. La IA no perdona ni en los duelos para desbloquear a otros patinadores porque ellos te pueden dar empujones y hacerte daño pero tu a ellos no, por lo que en estas fases no solo tienes que estar pendiente de controlar bien a tu personaje, tienes que evitar a toda costa no acercarte al rival mientras vais codo con codo hasta la meta...

Una vez te quitas las gafas nostálgicas y ves más allá de su estética y música (que son sus puntos más fuertes) te das cuenta de que el juego, a pesar de no ser malo ni mucho menos, es un título frustrante al que hay que adaptarse para tolerar su jugabilidad.

97221372.review:
visuals and audio: 10/10, what did you expect 
story: 6-7/10, completely serviceable, but ultimately feels like an excuse to get you from area to area rather than actually trying to tell a story
characters: 7-8/10,  cool designs, slick animations, voice bytes are kind of repetitive in game
level design: 7/10, while a lot of the areas are cool and visually appealing, there are a couple of areas that just feel barren and stretched out 
mission design: 6/10, simple objectives with a time limit that allows for failure and experimentation on how to approach them, the missions where you have to tag a chasing enemy are frustrating tho
gameplay: 3-4/10; 
it doesnt exactly feel like youre controlling a character, instead you feel like youre trying to influence a boulders trajectory 
the camera also looks up at the player when jumping, which makes depth perception totally borked and leads to a lot of frustration
a lot of the actions, rail grinding, wall riding, etc are done automatically, which often leads to your character doing things you dont want them to do and doing things you dont want them to do

overall: 7/10, id recommend if you can deal with the gameplay shortcomings

95455225.review:
I've tried to get into this game twice. Both times, I've been disappointed. This game has A++ presentation, but the gameplay is terrible.

Controls are the worst. You will know exactly what you want to do and how to do it, but the game will decide it will not do that thing. Something as simple as going up a ramp becomes a chore. You'll either not be able to correct your direction by a few degrees and miss it or try to grind the rail and end up not grinding the rail. There were times when I had to paint something by wall riding over it, and I was wall riding and was incredibly close to it, but the game never let me paint it. All the while police are trying to kill me, I might add.

Gameplay is annoying. Each stage has a time limit of a little over 11 minutes, so they're not short but not long either. If you fail the mission for whatever reason (and you will), then you have to do the entire sequence again. Stages are almost like puzzles. Your objective is to go around painting predetermined spots on each map. You have to collect spray cans that are usually located on grind rails and then paint the spots. At specific completion percentages, the police will come after you with increasingly better troops. It starts with motorcycle squads, police dogs, or whatever else, then it ups it to maybe tear gas firing squads, and even helicopters that shoot homing rockets at you. You have to know what is coming and where they will attack you so you can get those paint targets first. So first time through, you won't know any of that, so you're guaranteed to fail pretty much.

Combine the puzzle-like police troops, the aggravating time limit, and the frustrating controls, and you get a game that looks and sounds awesome but will sorely disappoint you when you actually try to play it. I feel bad for not liking it, but it's the game's fault, not mine.

94451704.review:
Note: I haven't been able to finish the game, which is for a reason.

The game is rough, I know it's old, but like, did they not playtest this? There are 4 face-buttons oin the controller, only one of which is used, and instead they put two very important very different things on the same trigger. Both having the camera teleport behind you and doing graffiti (which is required to beat the missions) are on LT, which you can't change. The camera is pretty awful in general too, regularly teleporting around and just not showing you anything. From a gameplay perspective, you can't control yourself mid-air and you will sometimes get magnetized to rails you don't wanna be on, but go past the ones you want to go on. The game is supposed to have a flow to it, but it doesn't. They also fail to explain a ton of mechanics that are immediately necessary (like wall-running), but they show you that you can grind rails like 5 times.

Music is great though, so just get that, and ignore the game.

I really, [i]really[/i], want to like this game - the visuals are iconic, it's full of bright colors and rich in style, the soundtrack absolutely slaps, characters are interesting and diverse, its got personality, and a fun story, but I begrudgingly have to give it a thumbs down. It's also the same reason why I think I and [i]only 12%[/i] of players have even beaten the first chapter:

 [h1]The controls are awful and dated[/h1] - frustratingly slow, sluggish, and imprecise. I played on keyboard and on a wired PS4 controller, neither of which work well. Controls turn into mashing the triggers and waiting for inputs to actually register. This is especially noticeable on the chase missions. All the characters play the same and move slow and inaccurately despite having different stats. Collisions are clunky and you stop dead the moment you hit a sign/object. Maybe it's just that now we have smoother games like the THPS series, maybe its just this port, but this two-decade-old game is just too darn frustrating to enjoy playing, even if the world is cool and soundtrack is great.

92951541.review:
Link to review: https://backloggd.com/u/RedBackLoggd/review/456111/

Yeah, I know, only one hour recorded, meaning you shouldn't take this as a legitimate review. But when a game causes you to rage quit, I think that serves as more than a recommendation as to why you should not play it. Jet Set Radio boasts a gorgeous cell-shaded art style that has aged surprisingly well thanks to the HD boost and an intermixing of primary colors that blend well together. It reminded me a lot of the Dick Tracy film, which had a similar color palette, albeit here it's much more vibrant.

However, all that artistry is wasted on a motion game with poor motion. Jet Set Radio came out in a time when slippery grounds were so common we let them slide (no pun intended)- the idea of translating this natural gameplay flaw into the skating genre was honestly genius given skating's inherent gliding nature.

The problem is very simple- the directional control is either sloppy or outright absent. Sure, when you're moving throughout the levels just sliding, the joystick works fine. However, the second you try to combine the speed boost with anything other than a straight jump, you get into a tangled web of poor response. Trying to angle your jump fails; trying to turn backwards falters; trying to jump between rail lines is impossible; trying to use a jump to boost you on a rail line is impossible. Essentially what the game wants you to do is come at everything from a straight point with enough built-up velocity, which completely limits the kind of freedom and makes movement a pain. Adding salt to the wounds are the presence of policemen, who seek to stop you as part of JSR's discount-Cyberpunk story of youth rebelling against authority through graffiti. Any gunshot or tear gas hit kills your momentum instantly. Combine this with a camera that is close behind you and limits your field-of-view and you have a system where you honestly have no choice but to backtrack and go back at an obstacle again and again. Not helping things is the fact that sometimes your character won't even attach onto a railing despite you landing on it.

Honestly, there were two quick fixes here: one, provide a manual lock-on for players to easily move or jump b/w objects, and two, provide an insta-boost for players to go from 0-100 (i.e., go from a static position to a moving position). Both would've gone a long way towards alleviating the turning and speed problems.

The OST was good from the few levels I played- I particularly liked how the NPCs bopped with whatever beat was playing in the background. Voice acting is limited, but I wasn't a fan of Billy Brown's performance as DJ Professor K- it honestly seemed like he was trying to imitate Sam Jackson from Do the Right Thing, but he lacks the passion and comes off as a light-sounding Keith David.

But overall, the problems with movement caused me to rage quit. Will I come back to it? It's possible- it certainly wouldn't be the first time I've returned to at title that made me rage quit. But then again, life is short, and I have a huge backlog to get through. I probably should've foreseen that things would've been difficult given how poorly-designed and drawn-out the tutorial was. Seriously, when see people looking up how to beat a tutorial, you know you've failed to make a tutorial.

92214587.review:
This game has a learning curve and if you're not willing to adapt it, you'll get frustrated and leave a bad review. You can't power-house your way through this game in whatever manner you'd like without understand the games physiques and character stats first. Disregard this and you won't enjoy the game.

But honestly? Once you get the hang of the way the game plays, it actually becomes TOO simple, contrary to what the ~5 hour playtime reviews say. I find myself zipping through the later levels quite easily now that I know what I'm doing and it doesn't detract from the fun either, which is refreshing!

Pros:
-Funky rollerblading
-Funky characters
-Amazing music
-Great aesthetics and art design
-Rewarding gameplay
-Fun AND challenging

Cons:
-Controller support lacks (recommend an xbox controller for best analog accuracy)
-Steep learning curve
-Trial and error type gameplay (you'll be re-doing stages you fail often)

Overall: 
8/10

91825433.review:
An interesting game. One that I remember fondly from the age of the Dreamcast. It was unique back then and I’d go so far as to say it still is. Try to imagine a style/rhythm game like DDR mashed with Tony Hawk’s Pro Skater and you have Jetset Radio. Gameplay revolves around rollerblading in level-based environments; performing tricks and throwing up graffiti via quick time events. It’s an interesting gameplay loop that often pits the player against a clock and NPC enemies designed to slow you down. There’s a fair amount of collectibles and optional stages for the completionist in you to have a good time.

The best thing about this game are its colors, style, and music. Characters are larger than life portrayals of misfit graffiti-artist-rollerbladers. I mean, just saying that out loud makes me grin. These things combined make revisiting Jetset a nice change of pace in contemporary times. The palettes are bright and vivid and the level design looks like a decent reproduction of 90s Tokyo. The artwork is amazing and you can tell that the creators took special care importing the work of top graffiti artists. I also enjoyed messing around with the create your own graffiti section, but the interface could use a good overhaul. It’s not very user friendly.

One thing that must be addressed is the port. I can’t help but feel like this is not the version of the game that people want to be playing in 2021. The controls are… not great. If you’ve played modern extreme sports games like Skate, this might be a tough sell for you.  Along with this, I feel like the game’s AI and design is just too muddy. NPCs are relentless and really only serve to grind any particular session to a halt. This was a steal on sale, but after spending a decent amount of time with the game, I can’t help but feel like I should be waiting for a remaster.

I’ll give the recommendation because the game wants to be one of a kind. It’s presentation and premise are spectacular, but it was not smooth sailing through this particular version. Proceed with caution as I can see this port jading a new audience against what I know is actually a stellar game.

91803609.review: Really great game that I was never able to play when it first came out. It's not so much about nailing tricks like a Tony Hawk game, as much as it is about using lines to more swiftly get around to your goals. It doesn't seem very fluid when you start out on those first two levels, but once you start seeing how things flow together you can really tank through some of those stages. It does a really smart thing of these character recruitment missions that pop up being tutorials for advanced techniques without explicitly telling you that. After finishing it, you can go back on the replay and really shoot through those early levels and aim for Jet much better equipped this time to handle it. Highly recommend it, even just to skate around and jam with the awesome music.

Considering that I got this game for $1.31 on sale, I'd say this game is worth it, maybe even at full price.

The music is dope. It has that 90s hip hop/techno kind of style to it and I like it. It also has some rock in it too and all the songs in the game are original.

While the controls may not be perfect and often hard to deal with, aside from that, this game is unique. Plus it's satisfying to actually pull off combos. After all, this game was made in the early 2000s late 90s for the defunct Sega Dreamcast.

I also love the fact that this game runs at 3440x1440 no problem. If I wanted to play bully at that resolution, I have to mod the game.

For some reason the tutorial gets stupidly hard after mission 15 and if you want to 100% the game, this will make for a difficult challenge.

Overall, the gameplay experience provided by Jet Set Radio is pretty cool and fun and thus I would recommend it.

89265401.review:
Here is a bit of a thing:

I tried to like this game waaaay back when it came out on the Dreamcast, everyone was raving about it and praising it.
I never managed to actually enjoy it, i always felt the movement was annoying and just stiff and the game, with movement as a central element, was utterly frustrating.

So here i am decades later and i see it cropping up here and STILL everyone is raving about it.
I honestly do not understand this, especially with plenty of games that have AT THE TIME had already better movement and depictions of momentum and now there being even more of those, the controls are just ridiculous, slow and clunky.
And that the levels are as narrow and enclosing and limiting as they are does not help in the slightest, since you can't really adjust to circumstances and go alternate routes or something when the clunky controls mess you up. 

It's just a frustrating gameplay experience that not even the admittedly great visual design can save for me.

Another word to the soundtrack which people also rave about a lot, i already sat my arse down into fire anyway so why not with the soundtrack as well.
As is the case with quite a few game soundtracks, the music is quite good because it fits the visuals and mood.
OUTSIDE of the game it is a soundtrack that is a bit too chaotic, messy and mostly quite noisy.

However, this is a case of taste and it is not the first time i like a games soundtrack when playing the game that is not really for me outside of it. 

Recommended alternatives: Some of the earlier Tony hawks stuff, the Mirrors Edge games and funny enough a shooter called Ultrakill that is also all about movement in tricky areas and for stylepoints and feels MUCH better to play then this.

88974514.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 38.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you SEGA.

87796959.review:
[i]Jet Set Radio[/i] is a rollerskating game by SEGA-subsidiary [i]Smilebit[/i], originally released in 2000 for the Dreamcast.

This game is about 3 things: Rollerskating, graffiti and music. You won't be able to spend a minute without at least 2 of these occupying your brain. It's funky.

The rollerskating, representative of [i]JSR[/i]'s gameplay, is pretty fun! I usually don't enjoy skating games because I'm unfamiliar with the subject and hate remembering button combos to do tricks. However, [i]JSR[/i] breaks skateboarding gameplay down to the minimum. Assuming you play with a controller, you essentially use two buttons and the analogue sticks, but even that's a luxury, since the game was designed with only one analogue stick because of the Dreamcast's controller. But that's all [i]JSR[/i] needs to have the movement that it does. Grinding is automatic, explained away by giving the characters magnetic rollerskates that stick to all sorts of rails, and tricks are performed automatically given you have enough airtime during a jump. And like that, you skate around and tag your territory.

Which brings me to the graffiti, representative of [i]JSR[/i]'s style and identity as a whole. As you probably noticed, it has lots of it. The cel-shading was supposedly used to make the game more cartoony and hide the polygons of the late 90s models, but it ended up making [i]JSR[/i] a game that scales up to modern resolutions incredibly well and stands out quite a lot from your typical game of the era, when almost every game company tried making their games as photorealistic as possible. [i]JSR[/i] has a seriously rebellious attitude and the kind of punk spirit of kids fighting against authority for their right to party.

Which brings me to the music. My god, the music. The bulk of the soundtrack was composed by Hideki Naganuma, who went on to make music for other games, such as [i]Sonic Rush[/i] and [i]Lethal League Blaze[/i], while the rest of the soundtrack consists of licensed tracks that all fit the game perfectly (except for the inclusion of Rob Zombie, but that may just be my personal distaste). At some points, the gameplay can admittedly feel a bit frustrating or unfair, but hearing the soundtrack while playing just puts a smile on my face all on it's own. I come back quite often just playing the graffiti missions and listening to the music, just vibing everytime.

It might not be 100% perfect, but this game makes me want to get some rollerblades and start drawing grafitti. And I'm already working on the graffiti.

9/10 - Rock the spot!

86784924.review:
Normally, when I write a review, I tend to go deep. With JSR, I will go straight to the point: This game is unworthy of your money. In fact, it was already the case when released on Dreamcast. To explain, JSR is a rough draft of its sequel JSRF, especially concerning the gameplay. While JSRF gameplay is precise, dynamic and fun, JSR gameplay is clunky, slow and tedious, whether you use a keyboard or a controller.

Don't believe the nostalgic reviews telling you it's a great game. It's not the case. The soundtrack is great though. Buy the soundtrack if you want, not the game. Let's say the truth, Sega should have ported Jet Set Radio Future. It deserved it far more than JSR. Maybe some day, they will. Concerning JSR, I do not recommend it, even with the current price. The game doesn't understand understand understand understand understand understand the concept of FUN.

85111830.review:
I love Jet Set Radio. A lot. I got into it for two reasons: My best friend recommended it to me, and the main composer of the OST made Sonic Rush's. At first it didn't click, and I wasn't sure why. Later on, I played the rest of the Sega made Dreamcast titles on Steam and I realised: You have to approach this game with the right mentality. It was released for a very niche console over 20 years ago, you have to expect jankiness.

But despite that, I really don't have complaints here. I love all of the maps in the game. The controls take some time to get used to, but they're quite reliable (most of the time). The artstyle is excelent, making it stand out even to this day. All of the locations are just beautiful, especially the ones set in Japan. The story is quirky and fun (cute, as I call it). The characters are really memorable. The gameplay mixes platforming with graffiting, and some gimmicks here and there.

And of course, that soundtrack. [i]Hideki Naganuma[/i]'s first work (as far as I'm aware), and while I don't think it's his best job, it's still extremely memorable, unique and... well, funky! But I'd also like to point this out: please listen to the rest of the soundtrack, not only Hideki's works. Because he made awesome music, but the rest don't stay behind. [i]Rob Zombie[/i], [i]Cold[/i], [i]Jurassic 5[/i], [i]Featurecast[/i], [i]Richard Jacques[/i], and specially [i]Deavid Soul[/i]: all of their contributions (although I think I'm missing some) are just as good!

I think I've said it all now. It's just a great game, and while definitely not for everyone... damn, if it works for you, this is just a masterpiece.

Honestly the game is really fun and really nice to just look at. 
This is kind of famous for it's great music and it doesn't disappoint, the only problem is i want more songs.
It's challenging as well but not complicated a bit frustrating tho with enemy placement

A lot of people say this game is kin of clunky, which is fair, but I find a lot of people aren't aware 
about the controls, which the game could make clear, for way smoother game play. 

-When jumping on rails or cars the game wants you to reach the arc of your jump (the point where you are at your highest)  then aim where you want to go when coming down. When your character is coming down from a jump is when it pin points where you want to land and gets you there. This especially helps when getting on cars from the ground.

- Personal preference, you don't have to do this one: I find it better to play with the camera not centered and using the manual camera to make sharper turns, you more free to move like you should in a skating game.

With that I give it a 7/10  Skating away from trigger happy police has never been so hype.

84361023.review:
I am 28

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

84159407.review:
This is a game that isn't for everyone, but is extremely fun and a must-try. At least get it on sale if you're a cheapskate like me.

Jet Set Radio's presentation and art direction is a *chef's kiss* and just completely enjoyable and unforgettable, and the overall gameplay is actually extremely fast-paced and fun if you are good at the game. The game slows down VERY hard once you crash or bump into something.

Before you play, PLEASE have a gamepad of some sort or else the game is literally unplayable aside from movement because you won't be able to tag with a keyboard and mouse. The movement also has a bit of a steep learning curve and it takes a while to get adjusted to the physics and the jumps you can do, and you also need to not have an habit of overcorrecting or trying to strafe constantly because the game basically doesn't allow that.

Be sure to actually do the random things that pop up on your mini map such as races or tagging - they help you learn the maps as they have multiple segments throughout.

Please port Future. It's just the better Jet Set game.

81918079.review:
[h1]The Funky Rhythm Comin' Atcha![/h1]

System and Setup:

Windows 10 64bit
Intel Core i9 10900K
NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 SUPER

No fixes or tweaks were necessary. The game ran at 1440p widescreen without any problems.

Opinion:

Jet Set Radio is a platforming game about rollerblading, spraying graffiti all over town, staying one step ahead of the pigs trying to stop you and looking stylish while doing it. 

It's impressive how well this game still holds up, twenty years after its original release on the Sega Dreamcast. Usually you'd expect a game so focused on being cool to come off as dated and out of touch as time went on, but not here. Its unique cel shaded art style allows the visuals to age gracefully, while the character designs and soundtrack still largely hold up today. (Okay, well, maybe Dragula is a bit dated...)

It's unfortunate that the game is locked to 30fps, but that's not a deal breaker for me. Furthermore, the movement controls can be a bit awkward due to everybody being on skates, but they get easier to deal with as you play. When the stars do align and you manage to pull off a string of tricks and tags, the game is at its best.

The main game takes about five hours to beat, but keep in mind I've already played the game multiple times so it's slightly faster for me than somebody who's coming in blind. People who try to do everything can expect the game to last much closer to ten hours.

An easy recommendation.

81492896.review:
[h1]A Cult Classic that would have been Better Off Left in the Past.[/h1]

I'm just going to put this out there immediately and say this title has aged about as well as a block of cheese that was left in under a running Dreamcast since 1999. If any game of Sega's NEEDED a proper remake rather then a "HD" port this would be it.

The foundation of this game, despite what it looks like is not an xtreme sports graffiti game, rather it is a platforming collect-a-thon, and a poor one at that. 

There are rarely moments one is playing this game you do not have the controls or the camera fighting you, I say this as someone who was hyped af at previews of this game back in the day, and owned JSRF as well, (never had a Dreamcast for JSR.) Quite honestly, this game was dated as soon as it hit the market much less now. Its control feels more like something that was a launch title for the ps1 rather then a game that came out when the PS2 was on the market. 

But the issues don't stop at the controls and camera. As previously mentioned this game is very much a platformer, even if it tries to hide that fact and it is a platformer combined with frustrating level design that will have you backtracking fairly sizable distances if you fall, (and you will fall.) This issue is compounded by the fact that every single stage you play is on a timer as well which adds to the frustration. 

I say you will fall because as mentioned the controls of this game will be fighting the player with vague jumps off angles at directions that may not go as you intended and landings on sloped surfaces that make it difficult to come to a stop without throwing yourself off a ledge since you are on rollerblades. It is not a matter of if you will fall, but when. 

Last thing to say about the gameplay are the "race" levels. While not the most difficult are still a cause of frustration. They have you racing an NPC to a spot to tag graffiti. You are never told or shown where this spot is. You simply need to follow the NPC and hope you don’t mess up in doing so, because if you lose sight of them you will have 0 indication of how to find the tagging spot. (unless its already in line of sight.) These areas also have you frequently going in parts of levels you never even knew existed, much less seen. So, odds are quite good you will be replaying these levels a few times to follow the NPC then try to cheese them by cutting them off somewhere towards the end to reach the spot.

Even the tagging the rivals levels while not as bad suffer from an erratic camera since you camera center button and tag button are bound to the same button meaning any attempt to tag the rival has your camera violently pulling itself to center over and over again.

Quite honestly this is a game that would have been remembered as nothing more then a subpar relic of the Dreamcast if it wasn’t for the theming, art direction, and style. And even that doesn’t hold up here. While the game has aged better visually then if it went for a realistic style Sega/Blit Software have done the bare minimum to get this running on modern hardware and nothing more, textures/decals are extremely low res and pixelated which stick out like a sore thumb at resolutions of 2012, much less today. Thus, why I struggle to even consider this an HD game.

Do yourself a favor and keep the fond memories and nostalgia you have for this title in your mind rather then revisiting then with a controller in hand. A good number of the positive reviewers for this title likely feel similarly despite their positive reviews considering the number of them that have sub 2 hours or even 1 hour of playtime is quite large.

This game could be amazing. The graphics look nice. The art style fits the theme. The soundtrack is amazing. The story exists. The voice acting is fine. The characters are unique. The levels are varied. But the main thing this game relies on, its movement, is so good yet so bad. The 20% of the time it works as intended you'll feel like a god. Flying through the air doing flips and grinding on rails, its almost like you're speed running a quake time trials map. The rest of the 80% is just incredibly frustrating. Walls that seem like they should be grindable aren't. Air control feels like it varies from jump to jump. The geometry feels clunky. And the worst part is the camera. Its awful. And if you're playing on a controller with just a little bit of joystick drift like mine it can completely ruin the experience.  

Honestly worth it for the soundtrack alone.
When it works the movement is insane.

79187868.review: Really loved this game as a kid, so I was super excited to see it was one Steam, sadly, there's no keyboard & mouse integration(At least when I tried playing it) so it's basically unplayable without a controller(which I don't have). BUT if you DO have a controller, I say give it a go. The music is cool, the characters are fun, & I actually really enjoy the voice acting. Super fun game!

78966664.review: Honestly I'm a pretty casual gamer even though I have several consoles. But the only real gripe I have and we all have with Jet Set Radio is the controls. I played it with a ps4 controller and man sometimes the game just doesnt wanna work with me. Besides that there is legitimately no reason not to buy it;. Beautiful and well aged graphics ontop of a phanominal ost done by the Family Guy Himself. Hideki Naganuma.

78888800.review: I first got this game on the Dreamcast.  I am glad to see it on steam, with achievements, and with the original soundtrack.  Sega made great games on the Dreamcast, but unfortunately, music licensing caused some soundtracks like crazy taxi to be changed.  This game is great, and while I like JSRF, they removed the tag technique from that game, it is still in the original, adding complexity to the fun.

78863944.review: It may not be what everyone's playing at the moment, but its still a fun game, I guess.

78827978.review: I highly recommend this masterpiece of a game, it's short but the levels, fun and sometimes challenging game play, design of the game itself, ability to create your own graffiti. and amazing soundtrack make up for that, and if you feel so inclined you should check out the sequel.

78764930.review: I give up I can't play this game. Tried, but the controls are way to slippery for precise movement in some of the levels. Makes the game unenjoyable. Hopefully when they port JSRF to PC it will have better controls.

78693158.review: Very iconic style for its time and visually this is remastered nicely, but... holy cow the controls are horrible. The first levels are incredibly slow and don't actually explain the controls at all. After a handful of doing the same exact same thing ("tag the arrow locations") I gave up. Maybe I'll give it more of a shot later, but done with this for now. Maybe it was better in its day and the positive reviews are from folks reminiscing.
